ContentItems.Caption: Sexual reproduction enabled a greater amount of variation in cells. By combining the genetic information of two parent cells, the offspring were given a greater amount of genetic variability allowing them to cope with different environments and have a back up set of genes in case of damage. It also set the foundation for sexual selection which is now a very strong evolutionary force, creating a myriad of different organs, capabilities and behaviors.
ContentItems.Title: Haploid vs. Diploid

ContentItems.Caption: Salman Khan explains the process of sexual reproduction. Mitosis is the process by which a eukaryotic cell separates chromosomes in its nucleus into two identical sets, in two separate nuclei. Meiosis is a type of cell division necessary for sexual reproduction. Sexual reproduction is the creation of a new organism by combining the generic material of two organisms.
ContentItems.Title: Mitosis, Meiosis and Sexual Reproduction

ContentItems.Caption: Chloroplasts are not found in animal or fungi cells; only plant and algae cells contain them. They are similar in many ways to mitochondria. It is hypothesized that they have similar origins to mitochondria in that they were originally free living cyanobacteria that were ingested and later evolved within larger eukaryotic cells as endosymbionts. The function of chloroplasts is to generate organic molecules, especially simple sugars such as glucose, from CO2 and H2O. This is an extremely important function ecologically since it recycles inorganic molecules and creates molecules we can gain sustenance from by using solar energy. It carries out its functions through thylakoids and has two sets of reactions: light dependent which use chlorophyll A and B to break down water and create oxygen, and light independent (or Calvin cycle) which actually create the simple sugars and fixes carbon dioxide.
ContentItems.Title: Chloroplasts: Photosynthesis Centers

ContentItems.Caption: In this picture we can see the cytoskeleton of the several eukaryotic cells fluorescing. This skeleton holds cells together and maintains their integrity. It serves many of the same functions that a skeleton on multicellular organisms serves. The phospholipid bilayer on its own would not be enough to maintain the integrity of the cell so microtubules and microfilaments made of tubulin and actin protein polymers respectively create a network that keep cells shape. In fact these same proteins are what allow for many types of cellular locomotion such as pseudopod motion. Many proteins move across these tubes and filaments in order to move objects accurately to their destination. In animal cells, structures known as centrosomes made up of these tubes help guide mitosis, or cellular division.
ContentItems.Title: Cytoskeleton: The backbone and highways of the cell

ContentItems.Caption: The ER is a versatile organelle that fulfills a variety of vital functions in the cell depending on the metabolic needs. It is a network of membraned tubes with proteins on the surface. These proteins can change in number and variety based on stresses that the cell experiences, giving cells greater flexibility in a changing environment. There are two main types of ER, the rough and the smooth. The rough gains its name from the ribosomes on its surface that give it a grainy look when visualized through a microscope. It helps organize and coordinate protein synthesis. The smooth ER lacks these ribosomes and tends to focus on fat and steroid production as well as metabolizing toxins.
ContentItems.Title: Endoplasmic Reticulum

ContentItems.Caption: Eukaryote cells include a variety of membrane-bound structures, collectively referred to as the endomembrane system. Simple compartments, called vesicles or vacuoles, can form by budding off other membranes. Many cells ingest food and other materials through a process of endocytosis, where the outer membrane invaginates and then pinches off to form a vesicle. It is probable that most other membrane-bound organelles are ultimately derived from such vesicles.
ContentItems.Title: Internal Membrane

ContentItems.Caption: Mitochondrias are the sites in cells that produce all the energy that the cell needs to carry out it's functions. The energy it generates comes from breaking high energy bonds in organic molecules, which is released when these molecules form new low energy bonds as CO2 and H2O. The mitochondria uses that differential to generate ATP, the energy currency of the cell. The basic breakdown of glucose occurs in three steps: glycolysis, the citric acid cycle and oxidative phosphorylation. Glycolysis actually takes place outside of the mitochondria and involves the splitting of the glucose molecule in half. These halves then move into the mitochondria into the Citric Acid cycle. There the complete breakdown occurs. Finally all these electron carrier molecules pass through ATP synthase and for a total of around 32 ATP per glucose molecule. It is thought mitochondria originally were separate organisms that evolved inside eukaryotic cells and are now endosymbionts.
ContentItems.Title: Mitochondria: The power-plants of cells

ContentItems.Caption: Eukaryotes are different from prokaryotes in that they have membrane-bound organelles. This means that they are more compartimentalised and can therefore perform a wider range of chemical reactions. These cells also have a nucleus where DNA is stored and protected. Eukaryotic cells are also generally larger than prokaryotic cells and are the building blocks of all multicellular organisms, such as plants and animals.
ContentItems.Title: Organelles

ContentItems.Caption: Cellular membranes are made of a special kind of lipid called phospholipids. These have a head which is made up of a diglyceride and phosphate group, making it polar and therefore hydrophilic. This means it is attracted to water and can be dissolved in it easily. They also have a tail which is made up of a long chain of hydrocarbons making it non-polar. This means it is similar chemically to oily substances and has a difficult time dissolving in water. This makes it hydrophobic and avoid water. When millions of these molecules are put together, they create membranes that have two layers of these lipids, with the heads facing outward toward the water, and the tails facing inward towards each other avoiding the water. They can hold themselves together fairly well because of these inter-molecular forces but are also slightly permeable to water which allows for osmosis to take place.
ContentItems.Title: Phospholipid Membranes

ContentItems.Caption: Once the genetic information in the cell leaves the nucleus as mRNA it needs to be converted into proteins somehow before this information can be expressed, since proteins are what actually give organisms their traits. To do this, the cell utilizes ribosomes, organelles that are made up of both protein and rRNA, or ribosomal RNA. It is what you would call a ribozyme since it is an enzyme (protein) and a ribonucelotide. The way translation occurs is that the mRNA is fed through the ribosome and this ribosome reads it, three letters at a time. There are 64 different combinations, but only 20 amino acids that make up all proteins, so some amino acids have several three letter codes. As these codes are read, tRNAs with complimentary three letter sequences and one amino acid bound to them enter the ribosome from the top and begin assembling a chain of amino acids that will later become a protein.
ContentItems.Title: Ribosomes: Protein Factories

ContentItems.Caption: With eukaryotic cells being such complex structures, some kind of sorting mechanism needs to be in place. Proteins created by ribosomes are folded further here and packaged to go to their destinations within or outside the cell. It also plays an important role in the movement of lipids around the cell. Lysosomes, the main digestive sacs within the cell that contain hydrolytic enzymes, are also created here. In addition, proteins that can be found on the surface of cellular membranes often contain carbohydrates attached to them and this is where they are added, through a process called glycosylation.
ContentItems.Title: The Golgi Apparatus: The post office of the cell

ContentItems.Caption: The nucleus is where all the cell's genetic information is stored in the form of chromatin. Chromatin is the cell's DNA wrapped tightly around well packed proteins, that are there to protect the DNA from being degraded. The monomers of chromatin are nucleosomes, that bind together into chromosomes when the cell is ready to divide. The nuclear envelope is a double lipid bilayer that likely originated from an infolding of the cells normal membrane meaning the nuclear membrane is twice as thick as the regular cell membrane. Inside the nucleus, DNA is transcribed into mRNA. Most DNA is not actually genes that code for something important, but rather junk DNA that is there to absorb damage and protect the genes from damage, and then most genes aren't expressed in every cell, only a small subset are. The mRNA acts as a messenger of genetic information that exits the nucleus into the cytoplasm where it can be translated into proteins.
ContentItems.Title: The Nucleus: The Core of Eukaryotic cells

ContentItems.Caption: There was a time when the world went through an enormous glaciation that stretched almost from pole to pole, making the last one that humans experienced seem insignificant in comparison. Around 600 million years ago, the world was thrust into this ice age because much of the CO2 in the atmosphere was sequestered by plankton and taken out of the carbon cycle by being deposited as limestone. This reduction in greenhouse gases caused temperatures to plummet to an extraordinary degree, causing a global winter that only subsided after enough CO2 had been returned to the atmosphere by volcanoes. It is thought that this pressure on life around at the time sped up evolution and created the more resilient body plans that we see today.
ContentItems.Title: Artist depiction Snowball Earth

ContentItems.Caption: All higher plants had a common origin in green algae that originated in the ocean. Though they had to evolve substantially before they were recognizable as modern plants, the first steps were made in the ocean. Photosynthesis had been around for quite some time but they were the first plants to become truly multicellular. It is a very diverse group however and there are still single celled members in it, making it more basal than modern plants. One distinguishing feature besides the aquatic nature of algae and lack of a vascular support system is the flagella and mobility of algal cells at some stage, which land plants do not have.
ContentItems.Title: Algae and higher plants

ContentItems.Caption: When multicellularity arose something interesting happened known as the alternation of generations. Previously organisms were haploid, meaning they had one set of genes and that was it. This made them more prone to genetic diseases and if there was a harmful mutation in a vital gene, they would perish. When sexual reproduction appeared, organisms became more resilient because they had two sets of genes and became what is known as diploid. That is why we humans have 46 chromosomes, but we say we have 23 pairs. This allows for interesting mixes in recessives and dominants to allow for more variation and natural selection. The alternation of generations concept is that some organisms live part of their life cycle as haploids and part as diploids. Though we humans only have a short haploid phase as sperm and eggs, some fungi live mostly in a haploid state, while more primitive plants can be half in half living as sporophytes (diploid) or gametophytes (haploid).
ContentItems.Title: Alternation of Generations

ContentItems.Caption: All multicellular animals have different cell types that have specialized functions within the organism: muscle cells for movement, nerve cells for perception, hormonal glands, digestive cells for nourishment... but they all had to originate from one zygote that came from a sperm and an egg. This one cell divided and specialized into all the different types of cells present in the body, though every cell contains the same genetic information. Every division the cell makes is somewhat unequal, with more of certain proteins and organelles originally present in the zygote on one end than on the other. Based on this, certain genes are turned on or off in the daughter cells, and though the actual DNA is still there, how this DNA is used can be very different. This is the topic of epigenetics, or inheritance that occurs above the level of DNA. Pluripotent stem cells are special because they have the capacity to become any adult cell in the body.
ContentItems.Title: Cell differentiation and Stem cells

ContentItems.Caption: With multicellularity comes the necessity for tight cellular cohesion. As cells started to congregate into larger units, more strain was put on cells to stay together so to account for this, cells evolved different ways of sticking together. Desmosomes made of actin (the proteins that make up muscle cells) or keratin filaments (the proteins that make up your finger nails) are used to form strong connections between two cells. Gap junctions allow for materials to flow more freely through two cells, allowing for better communication. Tight junctions for when cells need to seal off a certain area, creating a barrier forcing everything to pass through the cell wall (like in skin).
ContentItems.Title: Cellular Junctions

ContentItems.Caption: It is still unclear how the first multicellular life appeared. One hypothesis is that colonial protists congregated and began to specialize in their functionality. This specialization would have then proven more beneficial to each individual cell than living independently and at some point the colony started to act more like a single organism and began further specialization. Today the most simple multicellular animals are sponges.
ContentItems.Title: Cooperation

ContentItems.Caption: It is thought that cycles of extreme glaciation almost to the equator and extreme greenhouse periods would have applied strong selective pressures and driven evolution. The first multicellular life is known as the Ediacaran biota and it predates the more famous Cambrian Explosion event. Many organisms from this period pertain to unknown or extinct lineages; they do not have modern descendants. Most were simple, soft and tubular organisms. Somewhere within this timeframe, all the modern lineages must have appeared and then suddenly diversified during the Cambrian explosion. The first true organs were developed somewhere during this time and can be found in flatworms and higher. They consist of parenchyma tissue which is the main component and stroma which differ but connect the organ to other systems.The development of true organs, rather than just specialized tissues is what ultimately kicked evolution into overdrive and is what makes the Phanaerozoic so full of macroscopic life
ContentItems.Title: Ediacaran Fauna, Snowball Earth and True organs

ContentItems.Caption: Though cells have been able to pick up chemical cues since their origins, multicellular life would require much more complex systems. Cells that were vast distances away from one another would need to communicate somehow. The endocrine or hormone system is made up of chemical compounds that travel through the blood or transport fluid of the organism to create a reaction in the cell. They can be protein which are usually faster acting such as adrenaline and lipids which usually induce DNA transcription and have longer term effects like steroids. The nervous system is the much faster acting system which uses ion channels to induce electrical currents through specialized nerve cells to send messages. Plants have complex communication systems as well, using pheromones and hormones to signal. Auxins induce cell growth, cytokinins induce cell division, GAs which promote germination and ethylene which promotes fruit ripening.
ContentItems.Title: Multicellular Communication

ContentItems.Caption: Cnidarians are another primitive group of organisms that are still around today. Jellyfish, sea anemones, corals and hydrozoans are all part of this category. Unlike sponges, these organisms actually have tissue layers, though no true organs. In addition, what separates higher animals from cnidarians is that all cnidarians have radial symmetry (meaning they can be cut into mirror images many different ways whereas things like humans only have one plane of symmetry or left and right sides). They also only have two germ layers from which all other cells originate whereas higher animals have 3 layers. They can be distinguished into medusas if their mouth cavity points down or polyps if it points up.  Some coral are unique and create large colonies that leave huge limestone deposits behind creating the vast reefs we see on tropical islands. Most cnidarians also have poisonous organelles that look like little harpoons called nematocysts that they use to stun their prey.
ContentItems.Title: Polyps and Medusas (Cnidarians)

ContentItems.Caption: Though they may at first glance appear to be some for of plant, sponges are in fact classified as animals. They may not move, but they have many of the traits that characterize animals such as cell specialization, heterotrophy and multicellularity among other common animal traits. There is much developmental and biochemical evidence that suggests that the first animals would have been similar to modern day sponges.
ContentItems.Title: Sponges (Porifera)

ContentItems.Caption: All animals more complex than sponges produce either 2 or 3 germ layers, or cell lines that give rise to all other organs and tissues. Cnidarians have two (endoderm and ectoderm) and everything from humans to insects to earthworms have three (those two plus a mesoderm). These cell lineages are called "multipotent" stem cells because they can become many different kinds of cell types within a certain range. The names are somewhat self explanatory: ectoderm gives rise to the skin, cornea and nervous system, the mesoderm creates the bones and muscles and the endoderm is mainly involved becoming the digestive system.
ContentItems.Title: Tissues and Germ Layers

ContentItems.Caption: When we talk about carbohydrates, lipids or proteins as being sources of energy we are being somewhat misleading. Though we do acquire energy when we consume them and we need them to survive, the actual source of energy for our bodies is a molecule called Adenosine Triphosphate, abbreviated as ATP. It is the universal molecule that cells use as an energy source to carry out its functions. What make's ATP so energetically charged is the fact that it has three very negatively charged phosphate groups bound very closely to one another. This repelling force held so closely together allows ATP to transmit it's energy to other systems by "phosphorylating" them. Essentially what this means is that some of that stored energy can be passed on to another system (such as an enzyme) by giving one of it's phosphate groups to it. To restore itself to ATP it needs to break down a complex molecule, continuing the cycle.
ContentItems.Title: ATP: The Energy Currency of Cells

ContentItems.Caption:
It took over a billion years of evolution for photosynthesis to appear in the first life forms and for enough oxygen to be created to change the atmosphere of the planet. However, when the atmosphere did change, it had an enormous impact on life. 

This rock from early in the history of photosynthesis is rich in iron, and the red portions are oxidized iron (hematite, or Fe2O3) that record the production of oxygen as a byproduct of photosynthesis and its absorption by iron. The red columns are stromatolites, or structures produced by the photosynthetic bacteria that produced the oxygen. The penny shows the scale.
ContentItems.Title: Banded Iron Formation (BIF)

ContentItems.Caption: Although the Great Oxygenation event caused a glaciation and mass extinction of many microbial taxa, it did make way for a new kind of chemistry life that would later come to be the dominant kind on earth. Oxygen is a very reactive molecule and can be damaging under the wrong conditions, but if utilized properly, it can be harnessed to produce a great amount of energy. Cells will use oxygen's high reactivity to break down complex molecules into simpler ones, and using the energy that process releases to carry their own cellular functions. The simplest version of this is the breakdown of glucose, the product of photosynthesis. It takes place in 3 steps main steps, the first where the glucose is split in half into two pyruvates. The second, or Krebb's Cycle, is where the pyruvates are broken down and used to produce a lot of NADHs, a carrier molecule. And the final step is Oxidative Phosphorylation, where the most energy is produced in the form of ATP.
ContentItems.Title: Cellular Respiration and Energy

ContentItems.Caption: Before photosynthesis appeared organisms carried out lower energy chemical reactions, using like hydrogen sulfide and methane. These were anaerobic reactions, meaning they didn't use oxygen to carry out. Organisms with this kind of chemistry still exist today, deep underground or near hydrothermal vents at the bottom of the ocean. For many in fact oxygen is damaging to them and they are usually known as extremophiles. It wasn't until much later that organisms were able to harness the power of the sun for energy. It is thought the first organisms were similar to modern cyanobacteria, or blue green algae. They are prokaryotic and don't have chloroplasts, only special folds in their membranes where the photosynthetic pigments are concentrated. In fact, modern theories suggest that chloroplasts in plants
ContentItems.Title: Cyanobacteria: The first photosynthetic organisms

ContentItems.Caption: Molecular oxygen is made up of two oxygen atoms double bonded together. It comprises about 21% of the atmosphere and it is what allows complex multicellular life to function. The way it does this is by a chemical process known as "Redox" or Reduction-Oxidation. Most elements want to be like Noble Gases (elements in the column of helium), which are non-reactive. This is because this is the lowest energy state they can be in, and is the basis for a concept known as electronegativity. An element is electronegative if it will try to gain electrons and an electropositive one will try to get rid of them. Oxygen is a good oxidizer, meaning it is good at accepting electrons because it is very electronegative. This makes it very reactive and capable of bonding with many different compounds. This makes it good for breaking down complex compounds and harnessing a lot of energy from them, allowing for much more chemistry and biological properties.
ContentItems.Title: Molecular Oxygen

ContentItems.Caption: Salman Khan explains the process of photosynthesis.
ContentItems.Title: Photosynthesis

ContentItems.Caption: All life on the surface of the Earth is solar powered in a sense. Granted there are several exceptions to this rule since there are bacteria that exist in the deep places of the earth that form the basis of food chains without the need for sun, through a process called chemiosynthesis. But for the most part, life depends on the Sun for energy. How this works on a molecular level is that plants use photons from the Sun (in the blue and red part of the spectrum, reflecting green back which is what we see) to break the bonds in water and CO2, and form new, higher energy bonds as sugars and they use chlorophyll as a pigment to do this. This sugars can then be broken down to create energy as ATP to power the production of other organic molecules, or used to build cell walls as cellulose, or stored as starch. As animals eat plants and the energy moves up the food chain, these high energy bonds move up as well, meaning we all run on solar power.
ContentItems.Title: Photosynthesis: Solar Powered Life

ContentItems.Caption: The first photosynthetic organisms didn't use chloroplasts or chlorophyll, but rather a pigment called phycocyanin that they contained in clusters phycobilisomes. What this pigment does is absorb different wavelengths of red and orange light, while reflecting blue and green ones, giving cyanobacteria their bluish green coloring. They used this absorbed light to red reduce carbon dioxide and oxidize water to produce molecular oxygen and sugars. Since they are water soluble, phycocyanins are stored in protein complexes in the membranes of cells.
ContentItems.Title: Phycocyanin

ContentItems.Caption: The Carbon Cycle is a very important and dynamic process by which elemental carbon cycles through the ecosystem. A variety of traits make it a good element to bond with and to create long polymers such as its ability to make 4 bonds, its ability to make stronger double and triple bonds, hybridized orbitals (where structures are stabilized and can transfer energy through electron resonance), and it's ability to hold positive or negative charges under different conditions depending on the bond needed to be made. This versatility is seen as it transforms through the environment as inorganic gaseous CO2 into organic sugars, fats and amino acids and then back into CO2. It can be subducted under the Earth's crust and then released by volcanoes as gas. It can even be dissolved in the oceans and act as a buffer against pH changes as bicarbonate. Without this cycle, life would go extinct very quickly, since carbon would accumulate in some form or another.
ContentItems.Title: The Carbon Cycle

ContentItems.Caption: Though calling this event a catastrophe may be a misnomer since life as we know it would not be able to exist without this event, it did cause a shift in worldwide biota and likely a mass extinction at a microbial level. Once oxygen producing organisms arose, many changes occurred to the physical environment. Oxygen caused a great amount of rusting of iron, leaving large formations. Once most iron on earth was rusted, the oxygen would have started to accumulate in the atmosphere, creating the ozone layer, an unstable form of three oxygen atoms bonded together, shielding life from harmful UV rays. However, not all the changes were good, the corrosive nature of oxygen meant that a lot of organisms were either damaged by it or the chemicals they utilized for metabolism disappeared or were confined to niche extreme environments. It also oxidize methane, a greenhouse gas, leaving Earth fell into a large ice age known as the Snowball Earth period
ContentItems.Title: The Oxygen Catastrophe

ContentItems.Caption: Amino acids are an amazing group of biomolecules because they are what truly gives life their versatility. They are the building blocks of proteins and proteins are the molecules in charge of carrying out enzyme reactions, metabolism, DNA replication, movement, cell regulation... they are the workhorses of the cells and they are what allow life to be 'alive.' Amino acids follow a simple core structure. There is a central carbon bonded to a hydrogen atom on top, an amine group to the left, a carboxylic acid group to the right and then a variable radical group on the bottom. This radical group can be anything and it is the one variable part in amino acids. Though there is virtually an infinite number of radicals that can be attached, the most amazing part about life is that all proteins come from 20 different radicals... Total. Everything from bacteria to humans is made up of the 20 different amino acids, just mixed and used in different quantities.
ContentItems.Title: Amino Acids

ContentItems.Caption: Salman Kahn describes the first forms of life. Prokaryotes are a group of organisms that lack a cell nucleus, or any other membrane-bound organelles. The current model of the evolution of the first living organisms is that these were some form of prokaryotes, which may have evolved out of protobionts.
ContentItems.Title: Beginnings of Life

ContentItems.Caption: With carbon as a backbone, groups of atoms bonded together with single, double or triple bonds can start being classified based on patterns of occurrence. These groups are called "functional groups" and are the basis of biochemistry. Different groups will have certain properties that react and interact with other functional groups in predictable ways to create more complex interactions. Many of the most common ones are simple, being composed of mostly oxygen, hydrogen and carbon. The rules become somewhat more complex when nitrogen, phosphorous, sulfur and things like electron sharing and resonance structures are considered, but overall the concept is simple: the building blocks don't need to be complex, for the structures they create to be.
ContentItems.Title: Biochemical Functional Groups

ContentItems.Caption: Carbon is the element that forms the greatest number of compounds in the periodic table. This has to do with it's chemical properties of having 4 valence electrons, or 4 electrons they can use to bind with other elements. This means it can form long chains, strong double or even triple bonds, stabilize bonds with something called resonance and act either as an electron donor or receiver. Life and all it's complexities requires things called "polymers," or long chains of atoms linked together to form complex molecules. Carbon forms the backbone to these polymers and is what all other elements attach to when forming large biological molecules. It is also strange to think of all the carbon can take which allows it to be versatile: it can be gaseous as carbon dioxide or methane, it can be oily or waxy or even solid as coal, graphite or even diamonds. This versatility allows it to cycle through ecosystems with ease.
ContentItems.Title: Carbon: The backbone of life

ContentItems.Caption: A living cell is an arrangement of organic and inorganic molecules working in unison to carry out higher functions: reproduction, metabolism and adaptation. All these processes are all just perpetual chemical reactions that are self regulated into a state called homeostasis. This cannot be achieved randomly and the information required is coded in DeoxyRibonucleic Acid or DNA. It is a double chained molecule, with a phosphate backbone made up of repeating sequences of monomers called nucleotides. There are four letters we use to represent this sequence of code: ATCG. The chains are complementary so A always bonds to T and C always to G. How this information gets expressed is that DNA gets read and transformed into RNA, a similar molecule that is only single stranded and replaces T with U. This then gets read by enzymes that create amino acid sequences that become functional proteins. These proteins are what make us unique and not our neighbor, monkeys or bacteria.
ContentItems.Title: DNA and RNA: The Universal Code

ContentItems.Caption: Carbohydrates are a type of macro-biomelcule that mainly consist of Carbon, Oxygen and Hydrogen. The simples monomers for 5 or 6 ring molecules such as fructose or glucose, with the later being the main product of photosynthesis and are sweet sugars. They are used mainly for quick energy since they are easy to transport between cell and can be broken down quickly. Long chains of these rings can be made to either store as energy, in plants as starch, and in animals as glycogen, or as structural supports as cellulose, the main component of plant cell walls. Sometimes they aid proteins in cell-to-cell signaling. Lipids or fats are similar but tend to have less oxygen and dissolve more poorly in water. They tend to be oily or waxy and also have diverse functions and are classified into three general groups. Phospholipids which make cell membranes, triglycerides which serve as energy storage and steroids which work as hormones or cell to cell signaling.
ContentItems.Title: Lipids and Carbohydrates

ContentItems.Caption: It is still unclear how the first lifeforms would have formed. Some scientists hypothesized that it could have begun in the depths of the ocean near hydrothermal vents while other propose that lightning in the atmosphere provided the spark of life at the surface. We aren't sure what came first, DNA or proteins, since you can't replicate DNA without protein enzymes and you can't create protein without a DNA code, though some have proposed that RNA came first since it has some of the properties of both. At some point, in order for life to arise it would have needed to compartmentalize itself away from the external environment, which is why cell membranes arose. These droplets which are similar to modern liposomes, or membranes without the cell inside, would have had the basic materials inside to replicate and create more identical droplets. Though they would have been simple cell precursors, known as protobionts, over millions of years they would evolve to become the first life forms.
ContentItems.Title: Liposomes and Protobionts: The precursors to Life

ContentItems.Caption: Carbon may be the backbone of life, water its solvent but there a lot more elements required to to make complex biomolecules. Nitrogen is another versatile element that is more abundant in our atmosphere than oxygen. It is a necessity for life because it is required to produce amino acids which make up proteins in our bodies. These proteins carry out every function in the cell from metabolism, to reproduction to movement. Without nitrogen we would not be able to produce these proteins, and that is why it is such an important nutrient in agriculture. Like carbon, it also cycles through the environment with ease, going from gaseous molecular nitrogen (N2), to liquid ammonia, to solid nitrates. About 96% of our mass comes from carbon, oxygen, hydrogen and nitrogen but many other elements are essential for life such as calcium and sodium and other ions for signaling and enzymatic reactions and phosphorous for DNA. All together, they add spice to life.
ContentItems.Title: Nitrogen and the "Spice of Life"

ContentItems.Caption: The word prokaryote means 'before a nucleus.' It refers to how these organisms lack a nuclear envelope to hold their genetic material, as well as any other defined compartmentalization for chemical reactions within the cell. Today most organisms fall under this category, known to us as bacteria, and they play a huge role in the biosphere, despite being so small. Prokaryotes are the most primitive forms of cells but are also a more diverse and different from one another than a human is different from a plant or mushroom. It is thought that all life can trace its way back to some common prokaryotic ancestor from which it evolved. It is known as LUCA: the Last Universal Common Ancestor.
ContentItems.Title: Prokaryotes

ContentItems.Caption: Water, just two hydrogens and one oxygen, is another universal need of life. Carbon's complex polymers exist and interact in water. It is very stable and has a high boiling point for a molecule of its size, allowing it to be liquid over a wide range of temperatures. It can absorb a lot of energy without raising its temperature much, allowing heat from chemical reactions to dissipate. It is a polar molecule: the oxygen holds the electron's slightly closer to itself than the hydrogens do placing a slight negative charge on the oxygen and a positive charge on the hydrogen. This has many implications for its ability to dissolve ions, needed in metabolism and homeostasis, as well as other polar molecules, allowing cell membranes to form. This polarity is also involved in how ice is structured, making water's solid state less dense than its liquid state, meaning that ice will float above oceans, insulating them rather than having them freeze from the bottom up.
ContentItems.Title: Water: The (almost) universal solvent

ChildTimelines.Title: First Union of Aragon and Navarre
Second Union of Aragon and Navarre
French Wars and Loss of American Colonies

ContentItems.Caption:
Since the fourth century BC, Rome had been served by the port of Ostia, located to the south of the mouth of the Tiber river. However Ostias harbour was too small to admit large ships like those which carried grain, an essential import for the populous capital. Large ships either had to dock further out and have smaller ships unload their cargo piecemeal or dock into the harbour at Pozzuoli and have the cargo unloaded and then taken overland to Rome. 
Suetonius notes (Diuus Claudius XX.1) that the creation of a large harbour to accommodate these ships was considered and then abandoned by Julius Caesar in the first century BC as too difficult an undertaking. Despite the enormity of the project and its substantial cost, Claudius initiated the construction of the large artificial harbour on the north side of the Tiber mouth in AD 42.
ContentItems.Title: Commencement of Construction of the Claudian Basin by Emperor Claudius

ContentItems.Caption: Marble statue of Emperor Claudius found at Gabii and currently at the Louvre Museum, Paris. (c. 1st century AD)
ContentItems.Title: Marble statue of Emperor Claudius

ContentItems.Caption: Plan of the site of Portus
ContentItems.Title: Site plan of Portus

ContentItems.Caption: The first-century bath complex (c. 40 m by 30 m) was comprised of multiple vaulted rooms of brick-faced concrete construction.
ContentItems.Title: Visual reconstruction of the Terme Della Lanterna

ContentItems.Caption: The great imperial undertaking at Portus was not without its perils. Tacitus (Annales XV.18.3) records that a raging storm destroyed some two hundred ships within the port, a noteworthy blow to the grain supply of Rome.
ContentItems.Title: Destruction of C. 200 Ships During a Storm in the Claudian Basin

ContentItems.Caption: Plan showing Claudian phase
ContentItems.Title: Claudian phase

ContentItems.Caption: Sestertius of Nero (RIC 1, no. 178) minted in c. AD 64 showing the Claudian harbour on the reverse
ContentItems.Title: Coin commemorated by Nero

ContentItems.Caption: The construction of the Claudian port took two decades to complete. A bronze coin issued in AD 64 commemorates the inauguration of the harbour at Portus under the emperor Nero. However the planning and construction of Portus appear to have been organized in such a way as to enable the harbour to function at a very early date as evidenced by the presence and destruction of two hundred ships in the harbour two years previous. Also Pliny the Elder (Naturalis Historia IX.5.14-15) relates the story of Claudius trapping a killer whale at Portus by closing off the mouth of the harbour with nets and then engaging it in combat.
ContentItems.Title: Inauguration of Portus - Commemorated With a Special Coin Issue Showing the Claudian Basin

ContentItems.Caption: The monumental colonnaded street which defined the western edge of the Claudian harbour (AD 42-64)
ContentItems.Title: Portico di Claudio

ContentItems.Caption: Sestertius of Trajan (RIC II, no. 471) minted in AD 112-114 showing the hexagonal harbour on the reverse.
ContentItems.Title: Coin commemorated by Trajan

ContentItems.Caption: Beginning in c. AD 110, Portus was expanded by the emperor Trajan (Pliny the Younger, Panegyricus XXIX.2). A new hexagonal harbour basin was excavated inland behind the Claudian basin and associated infrastructure was constructed around it including warehouses, a possible ship shed, a temple and an expansive and lavishly decorated administrative building which was later dubbed the Palazzo Imperiale. At least one canal, mentioned by Pliny (Epistulae VIII.17.1-2) and possibly also referred to in a fragmentary inscription (CIL XIV 88 = CIL VI 964), was created by Trajan as well. The inauguration of Trajans work at Portus was commemorated with a coin issue displaying a birds eye view of the hexagonal harbour on the reverse.
ContentItems.Title: Inauguration of the Enlargement of Portus by Trajan - Commemorated by a Special Coin Issue Showing the New Hexagonal Basin

ContentItems.Caption: Plan showing Trajanic phase
ContentItems.Title: Trajanic Phase

Exhibits.Title: Inauguration of the Enlargement of Portus by Trajan

ContentItems.Caption: The Palazzo Imperiale was a brick- and reticulate-faced concrete structure which covered nearly three hectares. Of its original three storeys, only the substructures and some of the first floor remain. The Palazzos trapezoidal plan was dictated by the spur of land between the two basins on which it was situated.
ContentItems.Title: Imperial Palace

ContentItems.Caption: Visual reconstruction of the front faade of the Imperial Palace (Grant Cox, ACRG).
ContentItems.Title: Imperial Palace visual reconstruction

ContentItems.Attribution: Click here to view full screen
ContentItems.Caption: Gigapan image of one of the cistern walls
ContentItems.Title: Gigapan of the Cistern

ContentItems.Attribution: Click to view interactive version (AutoCAD WS)
ContentItems.Caption: Plan of the cistern at Portus
ContentItems.Title: Inside the Cistern

ContentItems.Caption: The cistern complex at Portus
ContentItems.Title: The Cistern Complex

ContentItems.Caption: Grandi Magazzini di Settimio Severo, showing the different rooms opening southwards onto an internal courtyard
ContentItems.Title: Grandi Magazzini di Settimio Severo

ContentItems.Caption: Archaeological remains, particularly the epigraphic brick stamps, indicate a major period of construction at Portus in the late second to early third centuries AD. At this time, the Grandi Magazzini di Settimio Severo, a large warehouse, is constructed at the mouth of the hexagonal basin and a small amphitheatre is built adjoining the eastern faade of the Palazzo Imperiale. Significant phases of construction are also undertaken in other areas of the Palazzo Imperiale and in the area of the Grandi Magazzini Traianei to the south-west of the Trajanic harbour.
ContentItems.Title: Major Phase of Building Works Within Pre-existing Infrastructure at Portus

ContentItems.Caption: Visualisation of the small lighthouse near to the baths at Portus. Animation by Gareth Beale (Archaeological Computing Research group, University of Southampton)
ContentItems.Title: Small Lighthouse at Portus

ContentItems.Caption: Fully excavated latrine showing evidence for the marble flooring and expensive fittings
ContentItems.Title: Excavated latrine

ContentItems.Caption: Careful excavation of the latrine within the Imperial Palace
ContentItems.Title: Excavating the latrine

ContentItems.Caption: Computer reconstruction of the latrine within the Imperial Palace
ContentItems.Title: Visual reconstruction of the latrine

ContentItems.Caption: Aerial photograph of the remains of the amphitheatre shaped building.
ContentItems.Title: Aerial view of Amphitheatre

ContentItems.Caption: Ground Penetrating Radar results for the Amphitheatre at Portus. Animation by Gareth Beale (Archaeological Computing Research group, University of Southampton)
ContentItems.Title: Amphitheatre GPR

ContentItems.Caption: Visual reconstruction of the amphitheatre-shaped structure (exterior view)
ContentItems.Title: Computer reconstruction

ContentItems.Caption: Simon Keay discussing the amphitheatre shaped building
ContentItems.Title: The Amphitheatre

ContentItems.Caption: A significant Christian population is present at Portus by the early fourth century AD. A bishop from the Portus Romae is mentioned as having attended the Council of Arles in AD 314. In a letter written in AD 398, Saint Jerome (Epistulae LXXVII.10.1-3) refers to the establishment of a hostel at Portus to provide hospitality for Christians travellers. South of the mouth of the Trajanic harbour basin, an early form of a Christian basilica (consisting of a nave demarcated from the flanking aisles with a row of eight columns) is built in the mid-fourth century AD with further additions and renovations undertaken at the end of the fourth century through to the sixth century AD.
ContentItems.Title: Existence of a Bishop of Portus By This Date

ContentItems.Caption: In the early fourth century AD, Portus was granted municipal status. An inscription (CIL XIV 4449) found near the Trajanic harbour and dating to AD 337-345 denotes Portus as such in a dedication to the praefectus annonae by the ordo and popuius of the Flavia Constantinianae Portuenses.
ContentItems.Title: Date by Which Portus Was Granted Urban Status

ContentItems.Caption: Zosimus (VI.6) and Philostorgius (Ecclesiasticae Historiae XII.3) write that Alaric besieged and captured Portus in AD 409. The majority of the grain supply for Rome was still imported and stored at Portus at this time. By seizing Portus, Alaric threatened the Romans with starvation and certain death. The Senate capitulated to Alarics demands for lands and titles. However unrest and discord continued and the Visigoths seized the city of Rome in the following year, the first time the city had been sacked since 387 BC, nearly 800 years prior.
ContentItems.Title: Capture and Sack of Portus by Alaric the Visigoth

ContentItems.Caption: The Vandals led by Genseric sailed from North Africa and landed at Portus in AD 455 (Prosper, Chron. ad Ann., 455). After seizing the port, the Vandals marched on the Via Portuensis to Rome and, three days after the murder of Emperor Petronius Maximus, sacked the great city (Procopius, History of the Wars of Justinian III.5). Some historians consider this the event that marks the end of the Roman Empire.
ContentItems.Title: Capture of Portus by Genseric the Vandal

ContentItems.Caption: Iron ballista bolt from a 5th century AD context at Portus
ContentItems.Title: Iron ballista bolt

ContentItems.Caption: Procopius (History of the Wars of Justinian V.26) notes that in the early sixth century AD, Portus is protected by strong walls. With commercial activity decreasing in the later fifth century AD, the functioning area of Portus retracted and focused around the hexagonal basin. Rome was still heavily dependent on imported supplies so to further protect the port from external threats, the area of the Trajanic harbour and the Darsena were enclosed within walls. The remains of these walls still exist in part around the port and have traditionally, though erroneously, been assigned a Constantinian date.
ContentItems.Title: Construction of a Defensive Wall to Enclose the Hexagonal Basin and Associated Buildings and Infrastructure

ContentItems.Caption: In the Gothic War (AD 535-553), Portus was a primary strategic location which both the Byzantines and the Ostrogoths fought to hold. General Belisarius reclaimed Rome from the Ostrogoths in AD 536 with the support of the citys people. The Ostrogoths, led by Vittigis, made to take back the city. In AD 537, they seized Portus and, now having Romes crucial supply link in their possession, the Ostrogoths then besieged Rome (Procopius, History of the Wars of Justinian V.26.3-19). The siege lasted a year and resulted in disease and famine for both sides since although the Ostrogoths held Portus, the Byzantines had control of the seas. Suffering from lack of supplies, Vittigis ordered the Ostrogoths to abandon Portus which was then immediately occupied by the Isaurians (Procopius, History of the Wars of Justinian VI.7).
ContentItems.Title: Capture and Sack of Portus by Vittigis the Ostrogoth

ContentItems.Caption: During the Gothic War, Rome was besieged three times: first in AD 537-538, then in AD 546 and finally in AD 549-550. The third siege resulted in the Ostrogoths, led by Totila, taking control of Rome (Procopius, History of the Wars of Justinian VIII). After Totila was defeated by Narses at the Battle of Taginae in AD 552, the remnants of the Ostrogothic force present at Rome retreated to Portus. Too few in number to defend themselves against the advancing Byzantines, the Ostrogoths surrendered and the Byzantines seized control of Portus once again.
ContentItems.Title: Byzantine Troops Capture Portus

ContentItems.Caption: Evidence for the deliberate demolition of the buildings at Portus
ContentItems.Title: Destruction of Portus buildings

ContentItems.Caption: Turtle ships participated against Japanese naval forces that supported Toyotomi Hideyoshi's attempts to conquer Korea from 1592-1598, inflicting heavy losses. However, their historical role may have been exaggerated since "the entire Korean fleet probably did not have more than half a dozen turtleboats in action at any one time". Korean admiral Yi Sun-sin is credited with designing the ship. His turtle ships were equipped with at least five different types of cannons. Their most distinguishable feature was a dragon-shaped head at the bow (front) that could launch cannon fire or flames from the mouth. Each was also equipped with a fully covered deck to deflect arrow fire, musket-shots, and incendiary weapons. The deck was covered with iron spikes to discourage enemy men from attempting to board the ship. Claims that it was iron plated remain controversial.
ContentItems.Title: 16th Century Turtle Ship

ContentItems.Caption: The two Japanese invasions of Korea took place from 1592 to 1598. Toyotomi Hideyoshi led the newly unified Japan into the first invasion (15921593) with the professed goal of conquering the Joseon Dynasty Korea, the Jurchens, and eventually Ming Dynasty China, and the European Merchants. The second invasion (15941596) was aimed as a retaliatory offensive against Joseon Dynasty Korea and Ming Dynasty China as its ally. The invasions are also known as Hideyoshi's invasions of Korea, the Seven Year War (in reference to its span), and the Imjin Waeran in reference to the "Imjin ()" year of the sexagenary cycle in Korean.
ContentItems.Title: Japanese Invasions of Korea

ContentItems.Caption: About three weeks after the Battle of Okpo, Admirals Yi and Won sailed with a total of 26 ships (23 under Admiral Yi) toward the Bay of Sacheon upon receiving an intelligence report of the Japanese presence. On July 8, 1592, the fleet arrived at the Bay of Sacheon, where the outgoing tide prevented the Korean fleet from entering. Therefore, Admiral Yi ordered the fleet to feign withdrawal, which the Japanese commander observed from his tent on a rock. Then the Japanese hurriedly embarked their 12 ships and pursued the Korean fleet. The Korean navy counterattacked, with their newly completed Turtle Ship in the front, and successfully destroyed all 12 ships. Admiral Yi was shot by a bullet in his left shoulder, but survived successfully leading the Koreans to a resounding victory in the battle.
ContentItems.Title: The Battle of Sacheon

ContentItems.Caption: The Turtle ship, also known as Geobukseon or Kobukson (), was a type of large warship belonging to the Panokseon class in Korea that was used intermittently by the Royal Korean Navy during the Joseon Dynasty from the early 15th century up until the 19th century. The first references to older, first generation turtle ships, known as Gwiseon (), come from 1413 and 1415 though they are more famous for their role in the Japanese Invasion of Korea in the 16th century. The turtle ship was the fastest and most maneuverable existing warship in the East Asian theater, as it was powered by two sails and 80 oarsmen taking turns to handle the ship's 16 oars. Its primary role was to cut deep into the enemy lines, cause havoc with its cannons, and destroy the enemy flag ship.
ContentItems.Title: Turtle ship (1415-1592)

ContentItems.Caption: Dosan Seowon (alternatively, Tosansowon) was established in 1574 in what is present day Andong, South Korea, in memory of and four years after the death of Korean Confucian scholar Yi Hwang by some of his disciples and other Korean Confucian authorities. Yi Hwang had retired to the location in 1549 and begun construction on the facility, a private Korean Confucian academy offering instruction in the classics and honouring the sages with regular memorial rites. Like other Korean Confucian academies, Dosan Seowon serves two purposes: education and commemoration. The site was well known in Korea as one of the leading academies and was home to the Toegye School of Thought for over 400 years. Although the educational function of the facility has long since ceased, the commemorative ceremonies have been and are still held twice a year.
ContentItems.Title: Dosan Seowan

ContentItems.Caption: This picture shows the Joseon Dynasty's coat of arms. Joseon (July 1392  October 1897) was a Korean state founded by Taejo Yi Seong-gye that lasted for approximately five centuries. It was founded in the aftermath of the overthrow of the Goryeo at what is today the city of Kaesong. Early on, Korea was retitled and the capital was relocated to modern-day Seoul. The kingdom's northernmost borders were expanded to the natural boundaries at the Amnok and Duman rivers through the subjugation of the Jurchens. Joseon was the last dynasty of Korean history and the longest-ruling Confucian dynasty.
ContentItems.Title: Joseon Dynasty

ContentItems.Caption: This is a picture of Confucius, the founder of Confucianism. The Joseon Dynasty practiced a form of Confucianism, known as neo-Confucianism. The founder of Dosan Seowan, Yi Hwang, intended for the site to be an academic center for his interpretation of Neo-Confucianism, known as the Yeongnam School. Neo-Confucianism was an attempt to create a more rationalist and secular form of Confucianism by rejecting superstitious and mystical elements of Daoism and Buddhism that had influenced Confucianism during and after the Han Dynasty. Neo-Confucianism held that the universe could be understood through human reason, and that it was up to humanity to create a harmonious relationship between the universe and the individual.
ContentItems.Title: Neo-Confucianism

ContentItems.Caption: Yi Hwang (15011570) is one of the two most prominent Korean Confucian scholars of the Joseon Dynasty, the other being his younger contemporary Yi I (Yulgok). A key figure of the Neo-Confucian literati, he established the Yeongnam School and set up the Dosan Seowon, a private Confucian academy.
ContentItems.Title: Yi Hwang

ContentItems.Caption: The book is divided into 5 chapters: Naegyeongpyeon (Internal Medicine), Oehyeongpyeon (External Medicine), Japbyeongpyeon (Miscellaneous Diseases), Tangaekpyeon (Remedies), and Chimgupyeon (Acupuncture). The Dongui Bogam offered the philosophical values of Eastern Asia in addition to medical facts.
ContentItems.Title: Chapters

ContentItems.Caption: This chapter explains the acupuncture procedures for various ailments and disorders. The photo is a modern version describing acupuncture.
ContentItems.Title: Chimgupyeon: Acupuncture

ContentItems.Caption: The Dongui Bogam is a Korean book that was first published in 1613 during the Joseon Dynasty of Korea. The book was compiled by the royal physician, Heo Jun and is regarded as important in traditional Korean medicine. The title means "Mirror of Eastern Medicine" and the original edition is currently in the Korean National Library. In July 2009, the book became part of UNESCO's Memory of the World Programme.
ContentItems.Title: Dongui Bogam

ContentItems.Caption: There have been several print editions besides the original edition, both within Korea and abroad. The first Chinese edition was printed in 1763 and the first Japanese edition first printed in 1724.
ContentItems.Title: Editions

ContentItems.Caption: The first page of the book links the human body with heaven and earth with an anatomical map of the human body. This embodies Asian Perspective of nature.
ContentItems.Title: First Page of The Dongui Bogam

ContentItems.Caption: The Dongui Bogam is known as one of the classic books in the history of Eastern Medicine and still remains a key reference in the study of such medicine. It was published in many countries, including China and Japan. It's categorization of symptoms and remedies under the different human organs affected (rather than the disease itself), was a revolutionary development at the time. The book was written and compiled by the royal physician, Heo Jun, who is pictured here.
ContentItems.Title: Heo Jun

ContentItems.Caption: This chapter describes diagnosis and healing methods of various illnesses and disorders such as anxiety, over-excitement, stroke, cold, nausea, edema, and jaundice. This chapter also has a section for pediatrics and gynecology.
ContentItems.Title: Japbyeongpyeon: Miscellaneous Diseases

ContentItems.Caption: The internal medicine section explains physiologic functions of disorders of internal organs. The interactions of the liver, lungs, kidneys, heart, and spleen are explained.
ContentItems.Title: Naegyeongpyeon: Internal Medicine

ContentItems.Caption: This chapter explains the function of the visible parts of the human body and their various related illnesses. Body parts discussed are the skin, muscles, blood vessels, tendons, and the bones.
ContentItems.Title: Oehyeongpyeon: External Medicine

ContentItems.Caption: This chapter describes methods for creating remedies and potions such as the collection of medicinal herbs and plants, creating medication, and correct prescription and administration of medicine. All herbal medicine is categorized with explanations detailing their strength and common names for easy understanding. This photo is a modern oriental herb and medicine expose.
ContentItems.Title: Tangaekpyeon: Remedies

ContentItems.Caption: Ilseongnok or Diary of Self-examination is a daily record of events at court made in order that the monarch might reflect upon them, ostensibly towards better government. The extant record of the Ilseongnok covers the last 150 years of the Joseon dynasty, from 1760 (the 36th year of the reign of king Yeongjo who is pictured above) to the end of the Joseon dynasty in 1910. The Ilseongnok is a vital historical record, and along with the Joseon Wangjo Sillok, the Seungjeongwon ilgi, and the Bibyeonsa, constitute one of the primary historical sources for the study of the period.
ContentItems.Title: Ilseongnok (1760-1910)

ContentItems.Caption: The political system of the Joseon Dynasty was dominated by a Confucianist bureaucracy. The government officials were ranked in 18 levels, ranging from senior first rank (1) down to junior ninth rank (9) based on seniority and promotion, which was achieved through the royal decree based on examinations and recommendations. The power of the bureaucrats often eclipsed that of the central authorities, including the monarch. For much of the dynasty, a complex system of checks and balances prevented any one section of the government from gaining overwhelming power until 19th century when political power became concentrated in a certain family or individual. Political struggles were common between different factions of the scholar-officials. Purges frequently resulted in leading political figures being sent into exile or condemned to death.
ContentItems.Title: Joseon Dynasty Politics

ContentItems.Caption: The Annals of the Joseon Dynasty (also known as The True Record of the Joseon Dynasty) are the annual records of the Joseon Dynasty of Korea, which were kept from 1413 to 1865. The annals, or sillok, comprise 1,893 volumes and are thought to cover the longest continual period of a single dynasty in the world. During the reign of a king, professional historiographers maintained extensive records on national affairs and the activities of the state. Great care was taken to ensure the neutrality of the historiographers, who were also officials with legal guarantees of independence. Nobody was allowed to read the Sacho, not even the king, and any historiographer who disclosed its contents or changed the content could be punished with beheading. These strict regulations lend great credibility to these records.
ContentItems.Title: The Annals of the Joseon Dynasty

ContentItems.Caption: Uigwe is the generic name given to a vast collection of some 3,895 books recording in great detail the royal rituals and ceremonies of the Korean Joseon Dynasty (1392 - 1910). Combining text and very detailed illustrations, each Uigwe preserves the records of the Superintendency (dogam), set up temporarily to plan and carry out special state rites. These rites included investitures, coronations, weddings, banquets of many kinds, the painting of royal portraits, funerals and ancestral rites. Each Uigwe, which might fill several volumes, was written in several copies, either by hand or (for the History Archive copies) sometimes using wood blocks. One copy, distinguished by the outstanding quality of its paper, binding, brushwork and overall presentation, was intended to serve as the royal viewing copy.
ContentItems.Title: Uigwe

ContentItems.Caption: The Fortress was originally composed of four gates, a large wall, and 48 other structures built along the wall. Many of those original 48 structures have been lost to flooding, wars, or general wear and tear. Today the fortress features: a floodgate, four secret gates, four guard platforms, two observation towers, two command posts, two archers platforms, five firearms bastions, five sentry posts, four pavilions, a beacon tower, and nine turrets.
ContentItems.Title: Fortress Layout

ContentItems.Caption: The Fortress has four gates: Janganmun (north gate), Hwaseomun (west gate), Paldalmun (south gate) and Changnyongmun (east gate). Janganmun and Paldalmun are the largest of the four main gates, with Jangamun being the largest gate in Korea. The four main gates are encircled by miniature fortresses which were manned by guards. The photo is a nighttime view of the Janganmun.
ContentItems.Title: Four Gates at Hwaseong

ContentItems.Caption: The Haenggung (or detached palace) is a palace built within the walls of the Hwaseong Fortress to house King Jeongjo when he was away from his palace in Seoul. When he was not at the palace it was used by his delegated officials as an official base of government. The Palace was built in 1789 and expanded in 1796 when it became the largest Haenggung in Korea. Most of the palace was destroyed under the Japanese colonial period Restoration work began in 1996.
ContentItems.Title: Haenggung

ContentItems.Caption: Hwaryeongjeon is a shrine for King Jeongjo that was built in 1801. It was constructed in the first year of King Sunjo's reign in Jeongjo's honor. In this photo is the portrait of King Jeongjo that the shrine houses.
ContentItems.Title: Hwaryeongjeon

ContentItems.Caption: Hwaseong (meaning Brilliant Castle/Fortress) refers to the wall surrounding the center of Suwon, the capital of Gyeonggi-do, South Korea. The wall was completed in 1796 by King Jeongjo of the Joseon Dynasty to honor and house the remains of his father. The Suwoncheon, the main stream in Suwon, flows through the center of the fortress. The fortress was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Sit in 1997.
ContentItems.Title: Hwaseong Fortress Completed

ContentItems.Caption: A martial arts demonstration occurs at the Hwaseong Fortress daily from March to November by the soliders of Hwaseong. Twenty-four martial arts are demonstrated following the routine used in King Jeongjo's time as king.
ContentItems.Title: Martial Arts Performance

ContentItems.Caption: A royal guards performance occurs each Sunday from March to November. This ceremony is a reconstruction of that which was held in Hwaseong in the 1790s by the guards who were promoted.
ContentItems.Title: Royal Guards Ceremony

ContentItems.Caption: The wall is 3.57 miles in length and originally enclosed about .5 square miles of land. Although the southern section between the south gate and the location of the former south floodgate has not been rebuilt, the remaining part of the wall can be walked on foot.
ContentItems.Title: Wall at Hwaseong

ChildTimelines.Title: Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK) Soviet Occupation
Republic of Korea (ROK) Under American Occupation

ContentItems.Caption: In 1790, King Jeongjo of Korea commissioned a book called the Muyedobotongji which was an illustrated manual of Korean martial arts. This book, written by Yi Deokmu (, 1741-1793) and Pak Jega (, 1750-1805), described in detail Korea's martial arts of which an unarmed combat style of kicking and punching is extensively illustrated. It was published in four volumes and there is an additional volume in which the original Hanja characters are presented in the Korean script, Hangul. This is an example of an illustration found in the book.
ContentItems.Title: Muyedobotongji

ContentItems.Caption: The first volume of the Muyedobotongji is based on the earliest known Korean martial arts treatise, the Muyejebo (), written in 1599. The Jangchang, literally long spear, is a Korean weapon first described in the martial manual Muyejebo from the 16th century. The weapon was preferably made from the yew tree, but other wood could be used as well. It was considered the most effective conventional weapon on the battlefield due to its flexibility and length. The jang chang was widely used in the battle to retake the Pyong-yang Fortress during the 1592 war between Chosun (Korea) and Japan.
ContentItems.Title: Volume 1

ContentItems.Caption: The four volumes contain 23 chapters in which all 24 methods are explained. Gwonbeop means fist fighting method. According to the Muyedobotongji, gwonbeop was impractical for large scale combat on the battlefield, but was taught as an introduction to the martial arts. Soldiers learned gwonbeop prior to learning more complex weapons arts to master footwork and body control. It was also taught as a method of personal self-defense for Joseon warriors. Quan fa is a generic term used for open handed Chinese martial arts. Gwonbeop was developed based on the methods of the Shaolin Temple and the techniques of Jang Song Gye ( hanja: ). The hanja for quan fa and gwonbeop are the same. The chapter in the muyedobotongji dealing with gwonbeop was inspired by Chinese writings describing quan fa-techniques. It was the Chinese general Qi Jiguang who said that empty-handed fighting methods were impractical on the battlefield.
ContentItems.Title: Volume 4

ContentItems.Caption: The second and third volumes of the Muyedobotongji are based on the Muyesinbo (), written in 1759. The Woldo (literally moon blade), was a Korean pole weapon that closely resembled the Chinese guandao (also known as yanyuedao), though proportionally smaller. It was so named because of its curved blade. The Muyedobotongji describes its design: The length of the handle is six feet, four inches; the length of the blade is two feet, eight inches; and the weight is three pounds, 15 ounces. It usually had a spike on the end of the handle, and a feather or tassel attached by a ring to the back of the blade. There was a variant of the woldo, called the danwoldo, which had a bigger blade.
ContentItems.Title: Volumes 2 and 3

ContentItems.Caption: The Daedong Yeojido is a remarkably accurate map of Korea that was published in 1861. The Daedong Yeoji Jeondo, a single-sheet version, was later made from the orginial. The map was compiled by Kim Jeong-ho, a cartographer and geographer, who considered it to be his magnum opus (or great work).
ContentItems.Title: Daedong Yeojido

ContentItems.Caption: Kim Jeong-ho was a Korean geographer and cartographer during the Ri Dynasty. It is believed that he walked the entire length of the Korean peninsula, through mountain and valley, in order to research and compile his magnum opus, the Daedong Yeojido. This is an example of one of his maps.
ContentItems.Title: Kim Jeong-ho

ContentItems.Caption: Following the publication of a later version of the Daedong Yoejido, Kim is not heard from again. The most common story is that the Korean regent Daewongun, upon viewing the later version of Kim's great map, became obsessed by its inclusion of secrets necessary to Korea's national defense. This was in the context of French aggression against Korea and the Franco-British assault on China, and the resulting anxieties concerning foreign invasion. Kim Joeng-ho is thought to have died in prison following this. Little evidence has been found concerning his life or death. This is a photo of The Daewongun.
ContentItems.Title: Kim Jeong-ho's Death

ContentItems.Caption: Gojong, also known as Emperor Gwangmu  (September 1852  January 1919), was the twenty-sixth king of the Korean Joseon Dynasty and the first emperor of the Korean Empire. In response to outside pressure, he attempted to censor the Tongnip Sinmun after its criticisms of pro-Russia conservatives and its publication of secret Russian and Japanese documents exposing plans to exact concessions from the Korean government in December 1987. The foreign community feared that an active press might interfere with "concession diplomacy" by mobilizing the Korean public against the granting of special privileges to foreign interests. Ultimately, the government decided to expel Seo from Korea and allow the continued publication of the paper under Yun Chi-ho.
ContentItems.Title: Censorship

ContentItems.Caption: This is a picture of Kim Ok-gyun, the leader of the Gapsin Coup, which was a failed 3-day coup d'tat that started on December 4, 1884 in the late Joseon Dynasty of Korea. The Gaehwapa (Enlightenment Party) group of reformers sought to initiate rapid changes within Korea to open its borders. Thwarted by conservative factions within the Joseon court, particularly the pro-Chinese Sugup'a, they launched a coup d'tat attempt with Japanese support, seizing the royal palace in Seoul. Facing this threat, Queen Min secretly requested Qing military intervention, and after three days, the revolt was suppressed by 1500 troops of the Qing garrison led by General Yuan Shikai.
ContentItems.Title: Gapsin Coup

ContentItems.Caption: Seo Jae-pil, also known as Philip Jaisohn, (January 7, 1864  January 5, 1951) was a noted champion for Korea's independence, and the first Korean to become a naturalized citizen of the United States. In 1884, Seo, following Kim Ok-gyun, was involved in the Gapsin Coup, a radical attempt to overturn the old regime and establish equality among people. He was appointed the Vice-Minister of Defense. The coup was aborted in three days, as China intervened by sending military troops. Convicted of treason, Seo Jae-Pil lost his whole family and had to flee Korea for the United States to save his life. In 1894, Japan defeated China in the First Sino-Japanese war which occurred in the Korean Peninsula, and the Korean cabinet was filled with reformists who pardoned Jaisohn enabling his return in 1895. In Korea, he endeavored to politically educate people. He published The Independent to transform Korean people into an informed citizenry.
ContentItems.Title: Seo Jae-pil

ContentItems.Caption: This is the front page of the English edition of the Tongnip Sinmun, or The Independent. The newspaper was the first privately-managed modern daily newspaper in Korea. It was founded in July 1896 by a member of the enlightened Korean intelligentsia, Seo Jae-pil (later known as Philip Jaisohn) and ran until 1899. It constituted two different language editions: Korean and English. Originally, it was published every other day, but it developed into a daily newspaper in Korean with an estimated average circulation of between two and three thousand copies. The Tongnip Sinmun was historic in terms of its contribution to, and impact on Korean political and intellectual history, generally raising awareness despite a corrupt government that eventually forced its demise. It was the first newspaper printed entirely in Korean, extending readership to lower classes and women.
ContentItems.Title: Tongnip Sinmun

ContentItems.Caption: The idea of a sun-centered, or heliocentric universe was first published by Polish astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus in 1543. This model ushered in a new age of astronomy. It positioned the Sun motionless near the center of the Universe with Earth and the other planets rotating around it in circular paths, modified by epicycles and at uniform speeds. The Copernican model departed from the Ptolemaic system that had prevailed in Western culture for centuries before.
ContentItems.Title: The Copernican Model

ContentItems.Caption: SN1572 or B Cas (shown above), a blazing hot cloud of gas and debris in the constellation Cassiopeia, is the remnant of the type 1a supernova that Tycho Brahe and other astronomers and stargazers witnessed on November 11, 1572. This bright explosion deep in space demonstrated to astronomers that the Universe was alive and in constant motion.
ContentItems.Title: Tycho's Supernova Remnant

ContentItems.Caption: The German astronomer and mathematician Johannes Kepler demonstrated that the orbits of the Earth and the other planets were not perfectly circular, but actually elliptical. From his observations, Kepler elucidated three laws that describe the motions of celestial bodies in orbit, such as planets around the Sun. Kepler's laws are: 1. The orbit of every planet is an ellipse with the Sun at one of the two foci. 2. A line joining a planet and the Sun sweeps out equal areas during equal intervals of time. 3. The square of the orbital period of a planet is directly proportional to the cube of the semi-major axis of its orbit.
ContentItems.Title: Kepler and Elliptical Orbits

Exhibits.Title: Kepler's First Law of Planetary Motion

ContentItems.Caption: Neil deGrasse Tyson gives his reasons for why he thinks Sir Isaac Newton was the greatest physicist in history.
ContentItems.Title: My Man, Sir Isaac Newton

ContentItems.Caption: In 1859, Darwin published his famous work, "On The Origin of Species", which outlined his theory of evolution. Here, Salman Khan explains the underlying ideas. When people use "evolution" in everyday context they think of "change". Even though creatures over time have accumulated changes, there was no active process of evolution that happened. Rather, natural selection means that environmental factors may select for certain traits that occurs naturally in a population (variation.
ContentItems.Title: Introduction to Evolution and Natural Selection

ContentItems.Attribution: Craig Benjamin and David Christian lecture slides
ContentItems.Caption: Craig Benjamin outlines the key points of Darwin's theory of natural selection, which is the gradual, non-random process by which biological traits become either more or less common in a population as a function of the differential reproduction of their bearers.
ContentItems.Title: Natural Selection

ContentItems.Caption: Thomas Alva Edison (February 11, 1847  October 18, 1931) was an American inventor and businessman. He developed many devices that greatly influenced life around the world, including the phonograph, the motion picture camera, and a long-lasting, practical electric light bulb. Dubbed "The Wizard of Menlo Park" by a newspaper reporter, he was one of the first inventors to apply the principles of mass production and large teamwork to the process of invention, and therefore is often credited with the creation of the first industrial research laboratory. He is also the fourth most prolific inventor in history, holding 1,093 US patents in his name, as well as many patents in the United Kingdom, France, and Germany.
ContentItems.Title: "Genius is one percent inspiration, ninety-nine percent perspiration." - Thomas Edison

ContentItems.Caption: Marie Curie was a Polish physicist and chemist best-known for her pioneering work on radioactivity. Curie was awarded Nobel Prizes in both physics and chemistry, making her the first person to ever win two. Her achievements include a theory of radioactivity, the discovery of polonium and radium, as well as techniques for isolating radioactive isotopes. The Curie Institutes, major centres of modern medical research in Paris and Warsaw, were founded by Curie.
ContentItems.Title: Photograph of Marie Curie

Exhibits.Title: Marie Curie Wins her First Nobel Prize

ContentItems.Caption: Special relativity is the physical theory of measurement in an inertial frame of reference proposed in 1905 by Albert Einstein in the paper "On the Electrodynamics of Moving Bodies". It generalizes Galileo's principle of relativitythat all uniform motion is relative, and that there is no absolute and well-defined state of rest (no privileged reference frames)from mechanics to all the laws of physics, including both the laws of mechanics and of electrodynamics. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.
ContentItems.Title: Special Theory of Relativity

ContentItems.Caption: General relativity is the geometric theory of gravitation published by Albert Einstein in 1916. It is the current description of gravitation in modern physics. General relativity generalizes special relativity and Newton's law of universal gravitation, providing a unified description of gravity as a geometric property of space and time, or spacetime. In particular, the curvature of spacetime is directly related to the four-momentum (mass-energy and linear momentum) of whatever matter and radiation are present. The relation is specified by the Einstein field equations, a system of partial differential equations.
ContentItems.Title: General Thoery of Relativity

ContentItems.Caption: Michio Kaku, Professor of Theoretical Physics, summarizes the enormous contributions that Einstein has made not only to science, but to our everyday lives.
ContentItems.Title: Einstein: A 90 Second Summary

ContentItems.Caption: Salman Khan introduces deoxyribonucleic acid. Made up of nucleotides, sugars, and phosphate groups, DNA is a nucleic acid containing the genetic instructions used in the development and functioning of all known living organisms (with the exception of RNA viruses). Along with RNA and proteins, DNA is one of the three major macromolecules that are essential for all known forms of life.
ContentItems.Title: DNA Explained

ChildTimelines.Title: Faculty of Computational Mathematics and Cybernetics

ContentItems.Caption: Flynn and Girldez argue that globalization began in 1571, when Manila Bay became a permanent linkage between the Americas and Asia via the Pacific Ocean. Above is a sketch of Manila Bay in the early 18th century.
ContentItems.Title: Foundations

ContentItems.Caption: Previously impenetrable barriers, Atlantic and Pacific Oceans were transformed into super-highways during the sixteenth century due to advances in marine technology that permitted voyages of discovery. Transoceanic ships provided vectors through which trade goods, such as Spanish American silver, diseases, and unknown types of plants and animals were transmitted, together with humans and human cultures.
ContentItems.Title: How Did Globalization Become Possible?

ContentItems.Caption: "Globalization began when all heavily populated land masses initiated sustained interaction--both directly with each other and indirectly through other land masses--in a manner that deeply and permanently linked them"  (Flynn and Girldez 2008, pg 369).
ContentItems.Title: The Definition

ContentItems.Caption: Sixteenth-century China contained a larger proportion of world population than it does today, and also contained cities much larger than London or Paris, Western Europes densest at 200,000 residents each.  Wheat up north and southern rice nourished Chinese masses. The art above depicts China in the 17th century.
ContentItems.Title: A World Economy Dominated by China
