University of California President Benjamin Ide Wheeler persuaded Charles Franklin Doe to bequeath funds for the construction.
ContentItems.Title: Doe Library

ContentItems.Caption: The library building shall accommodate 800,000 volumes and 1000 readers. The Library Building should find its most appropriate location near the center of the concourse of other university structures and in the immediate vicinity of college or departments of instruction, and free space for future extension must be allowed. The Doe Library opened in 1911 to house an initial collection of over 160,000 volumes.
ContentItems.Title: North facade of Doe Library under construction

ContentItems.Caption: Sather tower houses a concert carillon on it's eight floor with 61 bells (the last added in 1983). The weight of the bells ranges from 19 pounds to the "Great Bear Bell" which weights in at 10,500 pounds. During the Fall and Spring semesters at UC Berkeley the carillon is performed 3 times daily for ten minutes. At noon the last day of instruction each semester "They're Hangin Danny Deaver in the Morning" is played because this song uses the original set of bells installed in 1917. Following that, the bells are silent until the end of finals.
ContentItems.Title: Bells

ContentItems.Caption: Jane Sather was the widow of Peder Sather. Jane donated money for two of the school's most famous landmarks: Sather Gate and Sather Tower.
ContentItems.Title: Jane Sather

ContentItems.Caption: Two melancholy bears top a bench donated by the class of 1920 to recognize the Sons of the University killed in the Great War outside of the Campanile entrance.
ContentItems.Title: Mourning Bears

ContentItems.Caption: View from the 8th floor observation deck. An elevator takes visitors up the 200 feet to the top of the bell tower. On clear days it's easy to view the whole Bay Area.
ContentItems.Title: Observation Deck

ContentItems.Caption: Sather Tower, more commonly known as The Campanile, is a bell and clock tower on the University of California Berkeley campus. It was designed by John Galen Howard, completed in 1914, and opened to the public in 1917. Sather Tower is the third largest Bell Clock tower in the world standing at 307 feet tall. The tower has 7 floors (some that are used to store fossils) with an observation deck on the 8th floor. Sather tower is a California Historical Landmark.
ContentItems.Title: The Campanile is Completed

ContentItems.Caption: In 1919, the grounds and buildings of the Los Angeles State Normal School on Vermont Avenue were transferred to the University to become the "Southern Branch." The Regents chose a new site in Westwood 6 years later, and classes began in 1929, two years after the campus had been renamed the Unviersity of California at Los Angeles. UCLA was an undergraduate institution in the early 1930s, but graduate instruction was authorized in 1933, and the first Ph.D. was conferred in 1938. Professional schools followed with engineering in 1945. The School of Medicine began in 1947.
ContentItems.Title: Southern Branch

ContentItems.Caption: Amid the chaparral-covered hills of Westwood,the four original campus buildings can be seen. That includes Royce Hall, the Chemistry (Kinsey), Physics-Biology (Haines) buildings, and the library (Powell).
ContentItems.Title: UCLA Aerial View

ContentItems.Caption: Berkelium, atomic element number 97, was discovered by Glenn T. Seaborg, Albert Ghiorso, Stanley G. Thompson and Kenneth Street in December 1949 at Berkeley Laboratories.
ContentItems.Title: Discovery of Berkelium

ContentItems.Caption: After the UC banned all political activity on campus on December 2nd around 1,500 (and ultimately 4,000) students went to Sproul Plaza in order to re-open negotiations with the administration on the subject of restrictions in political speech and action on campus. The students remained peaceful at their sit-in at the Plaza and Mario Savio gave his famous speech on the steps of Sproul Hall. Around midnight a call for a mass arrest was made. The police arrested close to 800 students who were bussed to the Dublin Jail. They were released on their own after a few hours, but the University pressed chargers against the students who organized the sit in. Eventually the University officials backed down and established new rules for polical activities on campus.
ContentItems.Title: December 2, 1964

ContentItems.Caption: The play refers to a last second kickoff return during the Nov 20, 1982 Big Game between the UC Berkeley Bears and Stanford University. It is recognized as one of the most memorable plays in college football history. After Stanford had taken the lead on a field goal with four seconds left in the game the Bears used five lateral passes on the return to score the winning touchdown and victory. Midway through the return members of the Stanford Band rushed the field believing the game was over. To this day they play sparks intense disagreement.
ContentItems.Title: "The Play"

ContentItems.Caption: The Gardner Main Stacks is a four-story underground structure that is made up of 52 miles of bookshelves. During the Main Stacks construction Memorial Glade was dug out to build the four story structure that lies underneath the grassy glade.
ContentItems.Title: Construction of Gardner Stacks

ContentItems.Caption: Memorial Glade is a grassy noll on Berkeley's campus perfect for leisure activities like frisbee, and studying. The glade was initially part of John Galen Howard's initial student plan, but was overwhelmed by temporary buildings and the construction of Gardner Stacks.
ContentItems.Title: Memorial Glade is Completed

ContentItems.Caption: At the corner of Memorial Glade is a pool honoring the members of the campus community who lost their lives in World War Two.
ContentItems.Title: Memorial Pool

ContentItems.Caption: Cal Day 2012 is an annual festival where the entire University throws open its doors and puts on 300+ free lectures, performances, tours, concerts and more to showcase the campus, its students and the schools programs.
ContentItems.Title: Sather Gate on Cal Day

ContentItems.Caption: The R. Lowry Dobson Memorial Lecture was created in 1999 to commemorate the life and passions of Dr. Lowry Dobson, a Berkeley alumnus, faculty member and research scientist. Established by friends and family to honor Dr. Dobsons deep belief in the interdisciplinary exploration of concepts and ideas, this lecture series brings together scientists of all disciplines to share new insights, ask new questions, and find new answers to the challenges that face our world. Lectures rotate annually among speakers chosen by the deans of biological, physical, and social sciences.
ContentItems.Title: Robert Lowry Dobson, M.D., Ph.D.  (1919-1990)

Exhibits.Title: The R. Lowry Dobson Memorial Lecture

ContentItems.Caption: The day after Pearl Harbor the owner of this grocery store, an American man of Japanese descent who graduated from the University of California, put the "I am an American" sign on the store front. Following evacuation orders his store in was shut down. Photograph was taken at 13th and Franklin streets in Oakland, California.
ContentItems.Title: "I am an American"

ContentItems.Caption: Exclusion Order posted at First and Front Streets in San Francisco, California. The Exclusion Order called for the evacuation of all persons of Japanese descent due to Executive Order 9066. The executive order was signed and issued during World War II by U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt authorizing the Secretary of War to prescribe areas as military zones. The Order eventually cleared the way for the relocation of Japanese Americans to internment camps.
ContentItems.Title: Exclusion Order

ContentItems.Attribution: General Records of the United States, National Archives
ContentItems.Caption: The actual text of Executive Order 9066 signed by President Roosevelt. 9066 called for the evacuation of all Japanese Americans living on the West Coast. The order forced Japanese Americans to reside in Internment Camps (also called Relocation Camps) for the duration of the war.
ContentItems.Title: Executive Order 9066

ContentItems.Caption: Japanese American farm families board evacuation buses in Centerville, California. The evacuees will be housed in War Relocation Authority centers for the duration of World War Two.
ContentItems.Title: Japanese Americans Board Evacuation Buses

ContentItems.Caption: Japanese Americans load evacuation trucks in Oakland, California. The trucks will take the baggage to Assembly Centers where the evacuees will be housed.
ContentItems.Title: Japanese Evacuees Load Evacuation Trucks

ContentItems.Caption: Japanese American citizens reading the evacuation order that was posted in Little Tokyo. The exclusion order called for the internment of all persons of Japanese descent living on the west coast. The photograph was taken in Los Angeles, California.
ContentItems.Title: Reading Evacuation Order

ContentItems.Caption: A page from "The War Relocation Work Corps," a pamphlet for enlistees and their families distributed by The War Relocation Authority. This page defines terms that were commonly heard in reference to Japanese American Internment.
ContentItems.Title: The War Relocation Work Corps

ContentItems.Caption: Page out of evacuee Yoshika Uchida's scrapbook. Uchida was attending the University of California Berkeley when exclusion orders went out. He was forced to leave the University months shy of commencement and attended his graduation "via the press." The San Francisco Chronicle article featured mentions the way in which the students of Berkeley were gearing up for war.
ContentItems.Title: Yoshika Uchida Scrapbook Page 1

ContentItems.Caption: A page from Yoshika Uchida's scrapbook. This page has articles describing Japanese Evacuation, an envelope from his honorable dismissal from the University of California Berkeley, and a tag Uchida was given upon Internment with his number.
ContentItems.Title: Yoshika Uchida Scrapbook Page 2

ContentItems.Caption: A painting by Estelle Ishigo that depicts one of the common hobbies at Heart Mountain Relocation Camp, Baseball.
ContentItems.Title: Baseball Game at Heart Mountain

ContentItems.Caption: A photograph of boy scouts at Heart Mountain Relocation Camp conducting a morning flag raising ceremony. Photograph taken by Pat Coffey in Heart Mountain, Wyoming.
ContentItems.Title: Boy Scouts at Heart Mountain

ContentItems.Caption: A group photograph of Heart Mountain's camera club. Photograph was taken in Wyoming in 1942.
ContentItems.Title: Camera Club

ContentItems.Caption: A photograph of Estelle Ishigo and her dog. Contrary to popular belief evacuees were allowed to take animals to the internment camps.
ContentItems.Title: Estelle Ishigo and Dog

ContentItems.Caption: Football game between The Jack Rabbits and The All Stars at Heart Mountain Relocation Camp. Football was a common past time of Japanese Americans in the relocation camps.
ContentItems.Title: Football at Heart Mountain

ContentItems.Caption: Painting by Estelle Ishigo that depicts children gathering coal at Heart Mountain Relocation Camp in Wyoming. Notice the general feeling of melancholy the artist is trying to evoke.
ContentItems.Title: Gathering Coal

ContentItems.Caption: A painting by Estelle Ishigo depicting everyday life at Heart Mountain Relocation Camp. Her painting depicts life inside of a Japanese American household.
ContentItems.Title: Home at Heart Mountain

ContentItems.Caption: A painting by Estelle Ishigo of Japanese Americans at Heart Mountain Relocation Camp, one of ten internment camps used to incarcerate Japanese Americans excluded from the West Coast during World War II under the provisions of Executive Order 9066. Estelle will spend the rest of the war at Heart Mountain and will paint numerous depictions of everyday life there.
ContentItems.Title: Japanese Americans at Heart Mountain

ContentItems.Caption: New arrivals await instructions following arrival to Heart Mountain Relocation Camp. The Japanese Americans that have just arrived will spend the rest of the war at Heart Mountain.
ContentItems.Title: Lines at Heart Mountain

ContentItems.Caption: Photograph of the present Heart Mountain memorial. The memorial stands where the Heart Mountain camp was located.
ContentItems.Title: Memorial Plaque

Exhibits.Title: Estelle and Arthur Ishigo Arrive at Heart Mountain, Wyoming

ContentItems.Caption: A clothing request form submitted in order to get the basic clothing allotted to all Japanese American Internees. The clothes were thought by many to be of poor quality because they did not provide adequate winter protection.
ContentItems.Title: Clothing Request Form

ContentItems.Caption: Workmen erecting temporary barracks for the Japanese American evacuees. Photograph taken by Clem Algers in Pomona, California.
ContentItems.Title: Constructing Temporary Quarters

ContentItems.Caption: A portrait of Estelle Ishigo at Pomona Assembly Center. Estelle was a European American artist who went with her Japanese American husband Arthur to the Japanese Internment Camps during World War II. A painter and illustrator, Ishigo documented her experience through art and later published these works and wrote about her experience in her book, "Lone Heart Mountain."
ContentItems.Title: Estelle Ishigo

ContentItems.Caption: A sketch by Estelle Ishigo depicting the Main Street of Pomona Assembly Center. Estelle and her husband resided in Pomona, California until they were moved to a more permanent Internment Camp.
ContentItems.Title: Main Street

ContentItems.Caption: View of the construction of Pomona Assembly Center on Pomona Fair Grounds in California. The center will house Japanese-Americans for the duration of the war.
ContentItems.Title: Pomona Assembly Center

ContentItems.Caption: A page of the Pomona Center newspaper, Pomona Center News. This paper was issue number 14 released July 10th 1942.
ContentItems.Title: Pomona Center News

ContentItems.Caption: A photo of the Pomona Assembly Center News Staff. Estelle Ishigo is in the front row, second from the right.
ContentItems.Title: Pomona Center News Staff

ContentItems.Caption: A sketch by Estelle Ishigo depicting breakfast time at Pomona Assembly Center. Notice the long lines and children going about their everyday life.
ContentItems.Title: Waiting For Breakfast

Exhibits.Title: Estelle and Arthur Ishigo are Sent to Pomona Assembly Center

ContentItems.Caption: "70,000 American Refugees Made in the USA" is a short pamphlet written by Truman Douglas. Douglas argues that detaining the Japanese American citizens directly opposes the United States' principles of Liberty and Justice for All. The pamphlet puts for the relevant facts having to do with internment and suggests ways the reader can help to remedy the injustice.
ContentItems.Title: "70,000 American Refugees Made in the USA"

ContentItems.Caption: A "Letter to the editor" of the evening post from Mrs. Claire Sprague. Sprague was a teacher during World War Two who noted changes in her students during internment. The students who were not forced to leave their homes saved their money to send their friends in the camps toys and gum. This letter shows the common misconceptions present in the society of American during internment-such as the camps were similar to summer camps.
ContentItems.Title: "A Letter to the Editor"

ContentItems.Caption: "Outcasts: The Story of Americans Treatment of Her Japanese American Minority" written by Caleb Foote in 1943. "Outcasts" detailed the Japanese American Internment. Foote describes the way internment struck a "body blow" to the validity of the constitution.
ContentItems.Title: "Outcasts"

ContentItems.Caption: A song written by a Japanese American person in the camps. Songs, poetry, and other works of art were common mediums used to express the injustice felt by many of those that were forced to leave their homes.
ContentItems.Title: "Song of Topaz"

ContentItems.Caption: Japanese Americans voting before the beginning of World War Two and the law denying Japanese Americans citizens the right to vote is passed. The vote is for a councilman in San Francisco, Ca.
ContentItems.Title: Japanese Americans Voting Before Law is Passed

ContentItems.Caption: Sign in Oakland, Ca that depicts the prejudice against Japanese during World War Two. Prejudice against Japanese Americans led to the removal of the right to vote for Japanese American citizens.
ContentItems.Title: Oakland Sign

ContentItems.Caption: During World War Two the Prejudice against Japanese exploded. It is evident in the propaganda "Get in trim for fighting him" found in San Francisco, Ca. Prejudices like this led to the rights of Japanese American citizens being denied during the war.
ContentItems.Title: Prejudice Against Japanese Americans Explodes

Exhibits.Title: Law Denying Japanese Americans Right to Vote is Passed

ContentItems.Caption: A sketch by Estelle Ishigo depicting the uncertainty many Japanese Americans felt when it came time to leave the Japanese Relocation Centers. On December 18, 1944, the Supreme Court in Korematsu v. United States stated that the exclusion process in general was constitutional. Ex parte Endo unanimously declared that loyal citizens of the United States, regardless of cultural descent, could not be detained without cause.
ContentItems.Title: "Are we Americans Again?"

ContentItems.Caption: "Lone Heart Mountain" is a personal memoir written by Estelle Ishigo. The memoir details Ishigo's experiences during internment. This picture is of chapter one in its entirety, titled "Uprooting."
ContentItems.Title: "Lone Heart Mountain"

ContentItems.Caption: Page 6 of the Heart Mountain Centennial. The Japanese Americans at Heart Mountain published and wrote for this newspaper. The article titled "No Technical Authority For Holding US Citizens" is evidence for the tension felt by some about the Japanese Internment.
ContentItems.Title: "No Technical Authority For Holding US Citizens"

ContentItems.Caption: The American All booth at Pan-Pacific Industrial Exposition in Los Angeles. American All was sponsored by anti-racial civic organizations.
ContentItems.Title: Americans All

ContentItems.Caption: Photo showing Japanese Americans waving farewell while leaving Heart Mountain, Wyoming.
ContentItems.Title: Departees From Heart Mountain

ContentItems.Caption: On the sundeck of the SS Shawnee Japanese American children play awaiting their return home. The Shawnee returned over 1000 people to their homes in Hawaii.
ContentItems.Title: On a Sundeck

ContentItems.Caption: Baggage trucks waiting to load the train in Heart Mountain, Wyoming. Japanese Americans are able to leave the Relocation Camps for home for the first time since 1942.
ContentItems.Title: Outgoing Baggage Trucks

ContentItems.Caption: A page from a scrapbook of a Japanese American man who was in the internment camps. The page shows a portion of a date book where "VJ Day" is labeled. The Japanese Americans realized their freedom was close once the word about the war ending was out.
ContentItems.Title: V.J. Day

ContentItems.Caption: Sketch by Estelle Ishigo that depicts Victory in Japan Day at Heart Mountain, Wyoming. Japanese Americans were listening to the radio to hear the news.
ContentItems.Title: V.J. Day at Heart Mountain

ContentItems.Caption: The Winona Housing Project in Burbank, California. Here trailer homes were provided for returning evacuees while they secured housing. Photograph by Tom Parker
ContentItems.Title: Winona Housing Project

Exhibits.Title: Estelle and Arthur Ishigo Are Released From Heart Mountain

ContentItems.Caption:
Akira Kurosawa directed many controversial war time movies including "Sanshiro Sugata," "The Most Beautiful," and "The Men Who Tread on the Tigers Tail."  Released in December 1942, "Sanshiro Sugata" was considered too "British-American" but later became a critical success. In early 1944 "The Most Beautiful" was released; Kurosawa focused on Japanese war time factory workers. "The Men Who Treat on the Tigers Tail" was released in September 1945, Americans that occupied Japan considered the film too "feudal" and banned the work. 
Akira Kurosawa would later go on to release more movies and become one the greatest film directors of all time.
ContentItems.Title: Akira Kurosawa

Exhibits.Title: Akira Kurosawa Releases War Time Movies

ContentItems.Caption: For the first time in its history Japan is occupied by a foreign power. The Allies began their occupation of Japan following Japanese surrender during World War Two. Under General Douglas MacArthur the Allies demilitarized Japan, tried war criminals, and enacted important reforms to the Japanese school system and its industrial organizations. This is also the beginning of Japanese economic recovery and growth.
ContentItems.Title: General Douglas MacArthur

ContentItems.Caption: Thanks to the partnership with Microsoft Live Labs, version 1.0 written in Silverlight was released at the 97th Annual Faculty Research Lecture on April 29, 2010. Live Labs team: Bill Crow, Goldie Chaudhuri, Karan Singh, Melinda Minch and Asta Roseway.
ContentItems.Title: 97th Annual Faculty Research Presentation

ContentItems.Caption: Chronozoom is an online program that visualizes time on the broadest possible scale from the Big Bang to the present day. Conceived by Professor Walter Alvarez and Roland Saekow and developed by the department of Earth and Planetary Science at the University of California, Berkeley in collaboration with Microsoft Research and Moscow State University, Alvarez unveiled the first ChronoZoom prototype at UC Berkeley's 2010 Faculty Research Lecture. That demo is available to the public online, and a second version rewritten in HTML5 is now available and open source in beta form. ChronoZoom was inspired by the study of Big History, and it approaches the documentation and visualization of time and history in the same way that Google Earth deals with geography.  ChronoZoom allows users to see the true scale of time over cosmic, geologic, biological and social periods.
ContentItems.Title: ChronoZoom Version 1

ContentItems.Caption: Rane Johnson, Michael Zyskowski, Bob Walter, Danny Dalal, Kal Viswanathan, Roman Snytsar, Palani Vairavan, Jessica Herron, Jason Andrew, and Paul Secord
ContentItems.Title: Microsoft Research Team

ContentItems.Caption: Dr. Sergey Berezin, Alexander Zenchenko, Anna Isaeva, Dmitry Grechka, Dmitry Voytsekhovskiy, Eugene Nourminsky, Ivan Samylovskiy, Michael Kalygin, Nataliya Stepanova, and Nikita Skoblov
ContentItems.Title: Moscow State University Development and Test Team

ContentItems.Caption:
ChronoZoom is made by the academic community for the academic community.

In doing this we need your feedback to help us make it into the best teaching and research tool in building a bridge between the humanities and sciences.

Your responses to these 12 questions will help us prioritize the next set of features and user interface experience.

Please take the time to fill out this short survey to help us prioritize our next set of features and capabilities.

Thank you,
The ChronoZoom Team
ContentItems.Title: Take our Survey

ContentItems.Caption: Michael Zyskowski, Program Manager, introduces ChronoZoom at TechForum 2012.
ContentItems.Title: TechForum 2012 Demo

ContentItems.Caption: Mike Zyskowski introduces ChronoZoom as a tool for exploring "the history of everything." He explains that ChronoZoom provides a framework for examining historical events, trends, and themes, allowing researchers, educators, and students to synthesize knowledge from different studies of history, specialized timelines, and media resources. The platform for research and learning helps users develop a broad understanding of how the past has unfolded and discover unexpected relationships and historical convergences. Become your own time traveler!
ContentItems.Title: The History of Everything

ContentItems.Caption: In this Microsoft Research video the Chronozoom team discuss its potential as a tour for visualizing time. Roland Saekow came up with the idea of ChronoZoom in Walter Alvarez's Big History class where he was inspired to dedicate his student project at UC Berkeley to the study of timelines. This then sparked the inception of ChronoZoom as a way to examine the concept of Big History. Currently, teams in Berkeley and Moscow work together to further develop ChronoZoom.
ContentItems.Title: Time Traveling with ChronoZoom

ContentItems.Caption: Dr. Walter Alvarez, Roland Saekow, Chris Engberg, Michelle Lo, Ken Zhou, Matt Hoffman, Robbie Bruens, Madison Allen, Sergey Piterman, Cecily Gardner, Kenneth Leung, and David Shimabukuro
ContentItems.Title: UC Berkeley Content Team

ContentItems.Caption: Walter Alvarez, a geologist at the University of California at Berkeley, welcomes you to ChronoZoom. ChronoZoom is an open source, community collaboration between UC Berkeley, Moscow State University, and Microsoft Research to produce the first timeline tailored to understanding all of the pastfrom the Big Bang 13.7 billion years ago, to Todayin a single comprehensive view.
ContentItems.Title: Welcome to ChronoZoom

ContentItems.Caption: Andy Wilson, senior researcher and Hrvoje Benko, researcher, both from Microsoft Research explain their LightSpace research project.  LightSpace combines elements of surface computing and augmented reality research to create a highly interactive space where any surface, and even the space between surfaces, is fully interactive.
ContentItems.Title: Andy Wilson demos LightSpace

ContentItems.Caption: Switch to 2D View to view this data set. This image gallery contains 300+ image resources, artwork, and primary documents relating to the Industrial Revolution.
ContentItems.Title: Industrial Revolution Data Set

ContentItems.Caption: Microsoft Research was founded on the Redmond, Wash., campus of Microsoft Corp. in 1991 to support both basic and applied research without regard to product cycles.
ContentItems.Title: Microsoft Research Building 99

ContentItems.Caption: Microsoft Research (MSR) is the research division of Microsoft created in 1991 for developing various computer science ideas and integrating them into Microsoft products. It currently employs Turing Award winners C.A.R. Hoare, Butler Lampson, and Charles P. Thacker, Fields Medal winner Michael Freedman, MacArthur Fellow Jim Blinn, Dijkstra Prize winner Leslie Lamport and many other highly recognized experts in computer science, physics, and mathematics, including Turing Award winner Jim Gray up until his highly publicized disappearance while sailing.
ContentItems.Title: MRC Global Meeting: 2012

ContentItems.Caption: Visualize, explore, and discover new ways to look at data about the Earthboth above and below its surface. Layerscape enables scientists to gain environmental insights into our planet. Users can create and share 3-D virtual tours based on their discoveries and collaborate with the Earth-science community in ways that previously seemed impossible. Build your own virtual tours and experience the possibilities.
ContentItems.Title: Data Visualization Reaches New Heights with Layerscape

ContentItems.Caption: Abstract: The Earth is a vast, complicated system comprised of an astonishing collection of interlocking components with intricate interconnections. Earth scientists worldwide are attempting to work out the enormous puzzle of how the Earth functions as a system. One of the key technical challenges facing earth scientists is the management of the flow -- and particularly, the visualization -- of research data. Microsoft Research has a technological solution to the issue: Layerscape.
ContentItems.Title: Expanding Earth Sciences Research with Layerscape

ContentItems.Caption: A cloud-based user experience, Layerscape employs powerful, everyday tools to analyze and visualize complex Earth and oceanic datasetsenabling scientists to gain environmental insights into Earth. Users can create and share 3-D virtual tours based on their discoveries and collaborate with the Earth-science community in ways that previously seemed impossible. Build your own virtual tours and experience the possibilities.
ContentItems.Title: Layerscape

ContentItems.Caption: Creators Roy Gould and Curtis Wong introduce WorldWide Telescope at the TED Conference in February 2008.
ContentItems.Title: Roy Gould: WorldWide Telescope

ContentItems.Caption: Curtis Wong, co-creator of WorldWide Telescope, showcases WWT at TEDxCaltech on January 14, 2011.
ContentItems.Title: TEDxCaltech - Curtis Wong - WorldWide Telescope: The Interactive Sky on Your Desktop

ContentItems.Attribution: Alexander Szalay, The Johns Hopkins University; Jim Gray, Microsoft
ContentItems.Caption:
Abstract: All astronomy data and literature will soon be online and accessible via the Internet. The community is building the Virtual Observatory, an organization of this worldwide data into a coherent whole that can be accessed by anyone, in any form, from anywhere. The resulting system will dramatically improve our ability to do multi-spectral and temporal studies that integrate data
from multiple instruments. The virtual observatory data also provides a wonderful base for teaching astronomy, scientific discovery, and computational science.
ContentItems.Title: The World-Wide Telescope

ContentItems.Attribution: Jim Gray, Microsoft Research; Alex Szalay, Johns Hopkins University
ContentItems.Caption: Abstract: Most scientific data will never be directly examined by scientists; rather it will be put into online databases where it will be analyzed and summarized by computer programs. Scientists increasingly see their instruments through online scientific archives and analysis tools, rather than examining the raw data. Today this analysis is primarily driven by scientists asking queries, but scientific archives are becoming active databases that self-organize and recognize interesting and anomalous facts as data arrives. In some fields, data from many different archives can be cross-correlated to produce new insights. Astronomy presents an excellent example of these trends; and, federating Astronomy archives presents interesting challenges for computer scientists.
ContentItems.Title: The World-Wide Telescope, an Archetype for Online Science

ContentItems.Caption: Abstract: Scientists in all domains face a data avalanche  both from better instruments and from improved simulations. We believe that computer science tools and computer scientists are in a position to help all the sciences by building tools and developing techniques to manage, analyze, and visualize peta-scale scientific information. This article is summarizes our experiences over the last seven years trying to bridge the gap between database technology and the needs of the astronomy community in building the World-Wide Telescope.
ContentItems.Title: Where the Rubber Meets the Sky: Bridging the Gap between Databases and Science

ContentItems.Caption:
WorldWide Telescope (WWT) enables seamless panning and zooming across the night sky, blending terabytes of images, data, and stories from multiple sources over the Internet into a media-rich immersive experience.

WorldWide Telescope is a collaborative effort between Microsoft Research and a variety of academic and governmental agencies. Microsoft Research is making WorldWide Telescope available as a free resource to the astronomy and education community with the hope that it will inspire and empower people to explore and understand the universe as never before.
ContentItems.Title: WorldWide Telescope

ContentItems.Caption: A virtual tour on WorldWide Telescope being controlled by Kinect, another major Microsoft Research technology.
ContentItems.Title: WorldWide Telescope Kinect control

ContentItems.Caption: The base version of Microsoft's Windows 3.1 operating system first shipped in March 1992, with subsequent versions being released through 1994. This is a screenshot of the workspace from Microsoft's Windows for Workgroups 3.11, an extension released in 1993 that allowed for networking and resource sharing. These 16-bit operating systems led to an explosion of personal computer usage beginning in the early 1990s.
ContentItems.Title: Windows 3.1x

ContentItems.Caption: Above is the boxshot of Microsoft's Windows 95 operating system, which was released to the public on August 24, 1995. This hybrid 16-bit/32-bit operating system combined the previously separate MS-DOS and Windows products. Significant upgrades were made over previous Windows products, especially in the design and functionality of the user interface. Windows 95 was a tremendous commercial success, rapidly becoming the best-selling operating system in history. Staples of Windows operating systems, such as the "Start" menu and the taskbar, made their debuts in Windows 95.
ContentItems.Title: Windows 95

ContentItems.Caption: Shown above is the desktop layout for Microsoft's Windows 98 operating system, which was launched for retail on June 25, 1998. It was the second major release in the Windows 9x line, which also included Windows 95 and and Windows Me. Like its predecessor, Windows 95, 98 was a hybrid 16-bit/32-bit system that combined MS-DOS with Windows. Windows 98 was well-received and highly popular, with Microsoft maintaining support for it through July 2006.
ContentItems.Title: Windows 98

ContentItems.Caption: Windows Millennium Edition, abbreviated Windows Me, was the last installment of Microsoft's Windows 9x line of operating systems. Released in September 2000, Windows Me was designed specifically for home PCs, including entertainment software such as Windows Media Player, Windows Movie Maker, and Internet Explorer. Unlike Windows 95 and 98, Me featured limited access to real mode MS-DOS. Support for Windows Me was discontinued along with Windows 98 in September 2006. The box art for Windows Me is shown above.
ContentItems.Title: Windows Millennium Edition

ContentItems.Caption: Shown above is the workspace for Microsoft Windows XP, the first operating system in Microsoft's Windows NT line. Released in October 2001, Windows XP (short for eXPerience) shipped in Home and Professional editions, to cater to both home and business users. A third Media Center Edition was introduced in 2002 with upgraded digital media capabilities. XP became the second most popular Windows operating system ever, and from September 2003 to to July 2011, the most popular operating system for Internet access.
ContentItems.Title: Windows XP

ContentItems.Caption: Microsoft released its Windows Vista operating system worldwide in January 2007. Its launch came more than five years after that of its predecessor, Windows XP, the longest span of time between successive Windows releases. Vista featured a dramatically different visual style, and was designed to improve the security of the Windows operating system. Although not nearly as popular as Windows XP, Vista far-surpassed Microsoft's goal of 200 million Vista users after two years, having garnered well over 300 million users by January 2009.
ContentItems.Title: Windows Vista

ContentItems.Caption: Shown above is the desktop layout for Windows 7, Microsoft's latest and current PC operating system. Released for retail in October 2009, Windows 7 was intended to not make wholesale changes, but to make subtle upgrades on Windows Vista. It has been received positively by critics and users, citing significant improvements in security, performance, and usability. One of the most positively reviewed features is the functionality of the redesigned Taskbar.
ContentItems.Title: Windows 7

ContentItems.Caption: Founded in 1975, Microsoft is the worldwide leader in software, services and solutions that help people and businesses realize their full potential.
ContentItems.Title: The World of Microsoft

ContentItems.Caption:
Microsofts Internet Explorer team partnered with ZeptoLab (the creators of the game) and the specialists at Pixel Lab to bring Cut the Rope to life in a browser in HTML5. 

The end result is an authentic translation of the game for the web, showcasing some of the best that HTML5 has to offer: canvas-rendered graphics, browser-based audio and video, CSS3 styling and the personality of WOFF fonts.
ContentItems.Title: Announced at Microsoft 2012 CES Keynote

ContentItems.Attribution: Library of Congress Prints and Photographs Division. Brady-Handy Photograph Collection.
ContentItems.Caption: The Act was sponsored by Vermont Congressman Justin Morrill and signed into law by President Abraham Lincoln. The Act donated 30,000 acres of Federal land to states to provide colleges that benefit the agriculture and mechanic arts. The states sell the land to fund public colleges with the proceeds. As a result, 69 colleges were funded by the land grants, including Cornell University, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the University of Wiconsin at Madison, and the University of California, Berkeley.
ContentItems.Title: Justin Smith Morrill

ContentItems.Caption: Research into packet switching started in the early 1960s and packet switched networks such as ARPANET, Mark I at NPL in the UK,[6] CYCLADES,[7][8] Merit Network,[9] Tymnet, and Telenet, were developed in the late 1960s and early 1970s using a variety of protocols. The ARPANET in particular led to the development of protocols for internetworking, where multiple separate networks could be joined together into a network of networks.
ContentItems.Title: History of the Internet

ContentItems.Caption: In many cultures, dragons play a significant role in society or the belief systems. It is interesting to think about how they would have been different had dinosaurs never existed or their bones never found.
ContentItems.Title: Dragons in our Culture

ContentItems.Caption: For many centuries people have known about the remains of dinosaurs, through discoveries of their bones and other left overs. There was even a case where a shepherd had built an entire house out of the fossils! But people did not have a good explanation for the existence of these bones. Where were the creatures that left them? Such huge animals would have been an obvious presence. East Asian cultures used the explanation of dragons, European cultures reasoned they were wiped out by the great flood and did not make it onto Noah's ark, and it's possible that the Aztec's god Quetzalcoatl was originally thought of to explain these mysterious findings.
ContentItems.Title: Dragons or Dinosaurs?

ContentItems.Caption: Many depictions of dragons have remarkable similarities to theropod dinosaurs being depicted as bipedal and carnivorous.
ContentItems.Title: Similarities

ContentItems.Caption: In Judeo-Christian culture, Noah built a huge ark to house two of every animal on earth and shelter them from a massive flood that covered the earth. When bones of extinct dinosaurs were discovered people thought they were the remains of animals that were too large to fit on the ark, and thus perished.
ContentItems.Title: Too Big for the Ark

ContentItems.Attribution: Scan from The Illustrated Encyclopaedia of Dinosaurs
ContentItems.Caption: The discovery of Iguanodon got Mantell so excited that he hosted a dinner party inside of an inaccurate reconstruction of the creature. These statues still stand in Crystal Palace Park in England.
ContentItems.Title: Crystal Palace Dinner

ContentItems.Caption: The image of Iguanodon changed a lot over time but now we feel we have a fairly good understanding of what it must have looked like, behaved like and even eaten because of fossilized feces, footprints, nests and even skin imprints. Iguanodon was likely a highly active grazing animal much like today's grazers that would have been warm blooded and capable of running on two legs if in danger. However, most of the time it would have spent its life on all fours, with a rigid tail it used for balance. It also most likely traveled in herds where it would have found safety in numbers.
ContentItems.Title: Final Understanding

ContentItems.Caption: The first artistic renditions of Iguanodon depicted it as a huge lumbering monster that looked nothing like it does today. It had a much more fearsome appearance and the thumb spike was placed on it's nose like a rhinoceros. Many of these mistakes were because of incomplete fossil evidence but there were also anatomical mistakes because of limited knowledge about animals at the time and because this image fit nicely with our assumptions about dinosaurs as monstrous creatures from a bygone era.
ContentItems.Title: First Dinosaur Images

ContentItems.Caption: The first dinosaur to be discovered and acknowledged as a large extinct species of reptile was discovered by a paleontologist by the name of Gideon Mantell. Initially only consisting of a few teeth, and later being completed with more bones, the dinosaur he discovered was named Iguanodon, for it's iguana-shaped teeth.
ContentItems.Title: Gideon Mantell

ContentItems.Caption: Dinosaurs have fascinated Man for many years and captured the imaginations of millions during that time. Although we have only known dinosaurs as such for around two hundred years, stories of dragons and monsters created to explain their fossilized bones have been around for thousands of years. Dinosaurs have played an important role in the understanding our world in many ways, and their discovery has a history that is almost as interesting as the natural history of dinosaurs themselves.
ContentItems.Title: History of Dinosaurs

ContentItems.Caption: Iguanodon was a medium to large herbivore by dinosaur standards, that existed in the early cretaceous. It is classified as an ornithopod because of its bird-like hips and it had a distinctive thumb spike that would have allowed it to reach tall branches or defend itself from predators. It was a puzzling find for Mantell who did not immediately know what to make of such large bones and teeth but ultimately gave it the name Iguanodon because the teeth were similar to those of a very large iguana. However the final appearance of this and many other dinosaurs evolved over time as our understanding of dinosaurs improved.
ContentItems.Title: Iguanodon

ContentItems.Caption: Mantell's very first restoration of Iguanodon depicted it based off of very incomplete evidence and looking like an Iguana perched on a tree with a long lizard-like tail. Notice many important parts of the body are missing such as the skull and tail, which would have helped improve the accuracy of this picture.
ContentItems.Title: Mantell's Notes

ContentItems.Caption: Here is a picture of a more complete Iguanodon reconstruction. Here the thumb spike is accurately placed on the hand, and not the nose.
ContentItems.Title: Old Reconstruction

ContentItems.Caption: The term Dinosaur was first coined by Sir Richard Owen in 1942 to describe a group of large extinct reptiles that were being discovered around the world. The word itself means 'terrible lizards' and was chosen because of the awe inspired by the size of these grandiose creatures.
ContentItems.Title: Sir Richard Owen

ContentItems.Caption: It took some time for paleontologists to discover enough of Iguanodon to make an accurate portrayal of how all of the bones fit together. However certain aspects of its physiology and biology needed to be altered further. It still dragged its tail in most depictions and had a very lizard-like appearance to it. It was also shown as living near swamps and still had a somewhat lumbering feel to it. However, this was a good next step in our understanding of dinosaurs.
ContentItems.Title: Subsequent Restorations

ContentItems.Attribution: George Bird Grinnell and Marcus Benjamin
ContentItems.Caption: During the late 1800's, North America saw an explosion of new discoveries of dinosaurs, some of which are the most well known and complete specimens to date. This was largely due to two people, Othniel Charles Marsh and Edward Drinker Cope. They were both wealthy men who used their wealth to finance expeditions into the midwest. Between the two of them, over 130 new dinosaur species were discovered and named. This intense competition between the two often led to them destroying each other's finds and using underhanded means to gain an advantage over the other.
ContentItems.Title: Bone Wars

ContentItems.Caption: Though both men humiliated each other and were ruined from this feud, they left a lasting legacy. Between the two of them over 130 new species had been identified, some of which became the most well known species to date such as Triceratops, Stegosaurus and Allosaurus. Some of their ideas stood the test of time, such as Marsh's claim that birds are the descendants of dinosaurs. They also increased public awareness of dinosaurs and captured the public's imagination by bringing attention to the extinct creatures.
ContentItems.Title: Legacy

ContentItems.Caption: Both scientists made their fair share of mistakes. In his haste Cope put the head of Elasmosaurus, a marine reptile distantly related to dinosaurs, on the tail of the creature, thinking that the longer side of the vertebrae would have served as the propulsion mechanism for this creature. However, the neck on elasmosaurus was actually longer, as it used it to catch fish, and actually used its fins for propulsion, somewhat like a sea turtle. Marsh was sure to make this mistake evident to the public and humiliated Cope deliberately, but he was not infallible himself. He placed a wrong skull on an apatosaurus skeleton and declared it a new species: Brontosaurus.
ContentItems.Title: Mistakes

ContentItems.Caption: At times the confrontations became so bad that both men needed armed soldiers for protection and to protect their finds. Both men attempted to sabotage one another several times, publicly tried to discredit and humiliate each other and even steal or destroy each other's finds. Dynamite was even used by Cope to cover up a quarry that was no longer being used, just to make sure Marsh would not find anything he left behind.
ContentItems.Title: Ugly Confrontations

ContentItems.Caption: Bob Bakker was a major proponent of dinosaurs being warm blooded, smart and agile during a time when the established view was quite the opposite. He uncovered evidence about dinosaur nesting and was a strong supporter of the theory that birds evolved from dinosaurs.
ContentItems.Title: Bob Bakker

ContentItems.Caption: When first proposed, the idea of dinosaurs being related to birds seemed preposterous. After all, they were huge terrifying lizards that only had a thirst for blood. However, over the years as our understanding of dinosaurs grew, comparative anatomy between birds and dinosaurs improved, and more discoveries showed a closer and closer link between the two groups. It has become common knowledge that birds must have arisen from dinosaurs. With current genetic engineering, it has been shown possible to grow tails and teeth in chickens. The ancestral traits of dinosaurs have also been found within their DNA. However, some still scoff at the idea of a chickenosaurus.
ContentItems.Title: Chickenosaurus

ContentItems.Caption: Recent finds have shown that many dinosaurs had feathers or even wings that they may have used for display, warmth or even gliding. There are many anatomical similarities between certain small carnivorous dinosaurs and birds such as arm and hand structure.
ContentItems.Title: Feathers

ContentItems.Caption: When Jack Horner discovered hundreds of nests full of eggs and baby dinosaurs in them, and specimens of all ages around the area, he concluded that dinosaurs could in fact be good parents and actually raise their offspring. He even named the dinosaur Maiasaura, which means "Good Mother Lizard."
ContentItems.Title: Good Mothers

ContentItems.Caption: Jack Horner was one of the leading paleontologists during the Dinosaur Renaissance. He held the then unpopular position that dinosaurs must have evolved into birds. Now with many new finds, it is well established that birds are dinosaur's direct descendants. He also was a scientific advisor for the Jurassic Park movies.
ContentItems.Title: Jack Horner

ContentItems.Caption: Maiasaura was a large Hadrosaur, a herbivorous dinosaur that lived during the Cretaceous period. It lived in North America and was likely the prey of Tyrannosaurs. It's complex nesting behavior meant that dinosaurs were likely not the lumbering monsters they were traditionally depicted to be, but actually intelligent and highly adaptive creatures that acted in ways we would be familiar with ourselves.
ContentItems.Title: Maiasaura

ContentItems.Caption: Over the years, more and more discoveries of dinosaurs with feathers have been made. Most of these would have been closely related to birds and would have been in the raptor family, but increasingly it is being suggested that many other kinds of dinosaurs may have in fact had downy plumage. Especially in juvenile dinosaurs, it is thought the feathers would have kept the young warm, and in larger dinosaurs it would have fallen out. Microraptor is one discovery of a small raptor that would have acted much like a carnivorous flying squirrel, gliding from tree to tree, feeding on small prey.
ContentItems.Title: Microraptor

ContentItems.Caption: Halach Uinik (Mayan: Halach Uinik, "Man in fact Man of control") was the name given to maximum ruler, leader of a Mayan jurisdiction. The highest ranking person in each city was called the Halach Unic. The three main classes in Mayan society were royalty, wealthy, and poor. The royalty lived in palaces and led the Mayan empire. The wealthy lived in large houses around the palace to signify their wealth. The poor lived along the outskirts of towns in small huts and worked all day as slaves.
ContentItems.Title: Halach Unic

ContentItems.Caption: Tikal, a city of the Mayan civilization, reached its height during the Classical Period. During this time, the city dominated much of the Maya region politically, economically, and militarily while interacting with other areas such as Teotihuancn. One of the most studied sites is the North Acropolis. The North Acropolis (pictured here) developed into a funerary complex for the ruling dynasty of the Classic Period. Each additional royal burial added new temples and pyramids on top of the existing structure. The North Acropolis continued to receive burials into the Postclassic Period. It is located in present day Guatemala; the site is part of Guatemala's Tikal National Park.
ContentItems.Title: Tikal

Exhibits.Title: Tikal Becomes the Center of the Mayan Civilization

ContentItems.Caption: Maya writing, which consisted of intricate symbolic glyphs, was most commonly organized into columns two glyphs wide. As diagrammed above, reading and writing proceeded from left to right and down a column, with the bottom-right glyph of a column joining with the top-left glyph of the next column. Within each individual block, glyph elements were arranged top to bottom and left to right, with each block usually representing a noun or verb phrase.
ContentItems.Title: Maya writing order

ContentItems.Caption: The Maya script is the writing system of the Maya civilization. Maya writing used logograms complemented by a set of syllabic glyphs, somewhat similar to modern Japanese writing. Mayan writing has received official support and promotion by the Mexican government and is taught in universities and public schools in some Mayan speaking areas.
ContentItems.Title: Mayan Glyphs, Palenque, Mexico

ContentItems.Caption: The Mayans utilized a positional base-twenty numerical system that only contained whole numbers. Visually, a shell represented zero, while a dot and a bar represented 1 and 5, respectively. Numerals using combinations of these existed from 0 to 19. To count to greater figures, base-twenty place values were assembled vertically. Thus, the bottom position representing multiples of 1, the next position above it multiples of 20, then multiples of 400, 8000, etc. This figure illustrates how to calculate larger Mayan numerals from their visual representation.
ContentItems.Title: Mayan numerical system

ContentItems.Caption: This example of Maya writing is on display in the Museo de sitio in Palenque, a former Maya city state in southern Mexico. The Maya script was a logosyllabic system. Individual symbols, or glyphs, could represent either words or syllables. Ambiguity was common in Maya. Sometimes, the same glyph could be used for both a word or a vowel. In contrast, there are also many examples of different glyphs that can be read the same way. For example, the very common Mayan third-person pronoun u- was represented by at least half a dozen seemingly disparate glyphs.
ContentItems.Title: Palenque glyphs

ContentItems.Caption: The Jaguar Temple dates back to 625AD. It is named for its boxy jaguar decoration. The most interesting features of the temple are two masks at the west facade. The masks are human faces surrounded by decorative elements. The headdresses of the masks are representations of crocodiles. Lamanai, Belize is home to sizable Mayan ruins that used to be the ancient city of Lamanai meaning submerged crocodile. The name was a reference to the reptiles that lived along the bank of the New River. There is evidence that Mayan life here dates back to the Pre-classic period all the way through the Spanish Colonial period.
ContentItems.Title: The Jaguar Temple

ContentItems.Caption: The ballgame field becomes a place of transition, a liminal stage between life and death.
ContentItems.Title: Chichen Itza Ball Court, Cancun, Mexico

ContentItems.Caption: The Mesoamerica ballgame in Nahuatl was a sport with ritual associations played since 1,400 BC by pre-Columbian people. A modern version of the sport, ulama, is still played in a few places by the local indigenous population. The rules of the ballgame seem similar to racquetball, where the object of the game is to keep the ball in play.
ContentItems.Title: Mesoamerica ballgame in Nahuatl

ContentItems.Caption: The ball game was played in a large masonry structure. Constructed in a way that did not change much for 2700 years, over 1300 golf ball games in Mesoamerica have been identified, 60% of these only in the last 20 years. Archaeologists have identified thirteen ballcourts for playing the Mesoamerican ballgame in Chichen Itza, but the Great Ball Court is by far the largest and best preserved ball court in ancient Mesoamerica.
ContentItems.Title: Stone Ballcourt Goal

ContentItems.Caption: The Mayan myth of the Twins of the Popol Vuh states the importance of the game as a symbol of the war closely related to the theme of fertility. Called Hunahpu and Xbalanque in Quiche, the Twins could be considered as mythical ancestors to the Mayan ruling lineages. The game between Hunahpu, Xbalanque and the Xibalbans ultimately resulted in an embarrasing defeat for the Xibalbans.
ContentItems.Title: Twins of the Popol Vuh

ContentItems.Caption: Cancuen is an archaeological site of the pre-Columbian Maya civilization, located in the present-day Guatemalan Department of El Peten. The city is notable for having one of the largest palaces in the Maya world. During the Classic Period, Cancuen was a major city, reaching its peak during the 7th century. Tajal Chan Ahk, one of Cancuen's most powerful rulers built the city's palace in 770 AD.
ContentItems.Title: Cancuen Panel

Exhibits.Title: Tajal Chan Ahk built palace at Cancuen

ContentItems.Caption: The alignment of the pyramid construction allows it to observe various phenomena of light and shadow, which occur in his own body during the equinoxes and solstices each year.
ContentItems.Title: Alignment of the pyramid

ContentItems.Caption: This construction worshiped the god Kukulkan (Mayan language: Feathered Serpent), which is why you can see serpentine motifs in the architectural decoration. Kukulkan is the name of a Mayan snake diety. Although heavily Mexicanized, Kulkulkan has his origins among the Maya of the Classic Period, when he was known as Waxaklahun Ubah Kan, the War Serpent, and he has been identified as the Postclassic version of the Vision Serpent of Classic Maya art.
ContentItems.Title: Pyramid of Kukulkan

ContentItems.Caption: In 1988, the Organization of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), declared the Mayan city of Chichen Itza as a World Heritage Site.
ContentItems.Title: World Heritage Site

ContentItems.Caption: Mayan World markets were established for all people, offering among other things, products made from natural materials such as coconut, seeds, thorns, bones and sculpted and carved gourds. The luxury items such as pens, necklaces, and jade were exclusive to members of the elite. Open markets challenge the idea of a centralized food distribution system where foodstuffs were controlled by the ruling class, gathered in the form of tax and tribute and redistributed according to a complex set of social rules. Instead, market places imply that a free-market economy might have supplemented or co-existed with the tax and tribute system.
ContentItems.Title: Mayan World Markets

ContentItems.Caption: One of the more notable buildings of the Chichen Itza, Las Monjas is a complex of Terminal Classic buildings constructed in the Puuc architectural style. This building is considered a residential palace, but there are divided opinions among scholars. Some think that was the residence of the family that founded Chichen Itza or the government house or the high priest house.
ContentItems.Title: "La Iglesia" in the Las Monjas complex

ContentItems.Caption: It has a Puuc construction style, to which the Spanish called La Casa de las Monjas because its like a convent with a large number of rooms. Las Monjas means "nuns," but the place is actually intended as a governmental palace. The Las Monjas group is distinguished by hieroglyphic texts dating to the Late to Terminal Classic, that frequently mention a ruler by the name of Kakupakal.
ContentItems.Title: La Casa de las Monjas

ContentItems.Caption: A Tzompantli, or skull rack, is a type of wooden palisade that was used to display sacrificed human skulls by the ancient Mesoamericans. Seen here is the altar where the heads of the captives were sacrificed to honor the gods. The Tzompantli was most commonly erected as a linearly-arranged series of vertical posts connected by a series of horizontal crossbeams. The skulls were pierced or threaded laterally along these horizontal stakes. More common in the Maya regions, an alternate arrangement was for the skulls to be impaled on top of one another along the vertical posts.
ContentItems.Title: Altar

ContentItems.Caption: At some distance of the large platform are the remains of some small buildings, including a steam bath and a round tub built into the floor, which contains several steps and filled with water through a pipe. The doors and windows of El Caracol are aligned to astronomical events, specifically around the path of Venus as it traverses the heavens.
ContentItems.Title: Building footprints

ContentItems.Caption: This is one of the most important buildings in the holy city of the Itzes. "The Snail" is located to the North of Las Monjas. A round building on a large square platform, El Caracol gets its name from the stone spiral staircase inside. The structure, with its unusual placement on the platform, is theorized to be a proto-observatory.
ContentItems.Title: El Caracol

ContentItems.Caption: Some researchers found that the walls of the observation chamber had small slits visually oriented towards the four cardinal points. El Caracol may be an ancient Maya observatory building that served as a man-made marker, and provided a way for the Maya people to observe changes in the sky. Due to the flattened landscape of the Yucatn with no natural markers for this function around Chichen Itza, with the observatory one could view the sky above the vegetation on the Yucatn Peninsula without any obstruction.
ContentItems.Title: Four Cardinal Points

ContentItems.Caption: This tiny temple is located on the eastern side of the street and is the most richly ornamented in carvings and in paintings. Originally the structure was a one room building with a small altar attached to the wall. Temple of Frescoes dates back to the mid 1400s, and is a two-story building with colorful murals on the inner wall. It is thought to have been one of the last structures built by the Maya before the arrival of Hernan Cortez.
ContentItems.Title: Templo de Los Frescos

ContentItems.Caption: Mayapan is a Pre-Columbian Maya site in the state of Yucatan, Mexico. It was the political and cultural capital of the Maya during the Late Post-Classic period from the 1220s until the 1440s. Carnegie archaeologist A.L. Smith estimated 10-12,000 people lived within the walled parameter. People who lived outside of the city wall engaged in agriculture, animal raising, and specialized activities.
ContentItems.Title: Mayan ruins in Mayapan

Exhibits.Title: Mayapan became the capital of Maya

ContentItems.Caption: Tulum was first mentioned by Juan Diaz, a member of Juan de Grijalva's 1518 Spanish expedition. John Lloyd Stephens and Frederick Catherwood made the first detailed description of the ruins in 1843. Archaeologist Pilar Luna, a specialist in marine archeology in Mexico, explains that the importance of the building known as "The Castle" for Mayan sailors, was it allowed them to avoid the dangers of the second longest coral reef in the world.
ContentItems.Title: "The Castle"

ContentItems.Caption: Tulum has architecture typical of Maya sites on the east coast of the Yucatan Peninsula, recognized by a step running around the base of the building which sits on a low substructure. Until the early twentieth century, some villages used to visit the site to bring gifts but the steady stream of tourists made the practice obsolete. Some frescoes found inside buildings suggest some Mixtec influence in the community.
ContentItems.Title: Architecture of Tulum

ContentItems.Caption: Tulum is the site of a Pre-Columbian Maya walled city that serves as a major port for Coba. Along the east coast of the Yucatan Peninsula on the Caribbean Sea in the state of Quintana Roo, Mexico, Tulum was one of the last cities inhabited and built by Mayans. For the many records in murals and other works found in the buildings of the city, it is believed that Tulum was an important center of worship for the "god descending".
ContentItems.Title: The City of Tulum

ContentItems.Caption: Tulum or Tuluum Tulum was a walled city of the Mayan culture located in the State of Quintana Roo in southeastern Mexico on the Caribbean coast. Tulum was at its height between the 13th and 15th centuries. Having managed to survive about 70 years after the Spanish occupation of Mexico, it is believed that Old World diseases brought by Spanish settlers caused its demise.
ContentItems.Title: Tulum - The Walled City

ContentItems.Caption: The city received the name in ancient Maya Zama (meaning dawn in Mayan) and the current, Tulum (meaning wall in Maya), which seems to have been used to refer to the city when it was already in ruins. Having access to both land and sea trade routes, Tulum was made an important trade hub, especially for obsidian. Tulum had an estimated population of 1,000 to 1,600 inhabitants.
ContentItems.Title: Zama

ContentItems.Caption: The Spanish conquest of the Yucatan was the campaign undertaken by the Spanish "conquistadores" against the Late Post Classic Maya states. The campaign began in the early 16th century but would take about 170 years until the last recognized Maya stronghold fell. One of the first contacts was in 1517 when Hernndez de Crdoba sailed from Cuba in search of slaves. The Spaniards were surprised to see stone cities along the coast of the Yucatan and landed in several different cities. After Spanish dominion over the region was established the Maya people remained resistant under Spanish rule.
ContentItems.Title: The Spanish Arrive at the Yucatn under Francisco Hernndez de Crdoba

Exhibits.Title: The Spanish Conquest of the Yucatn

ContentItems.Caption: The Spanish conquest of Yucatan was the campaign undertaken by the Spanish conquistadores against the Late Postclassic Maya states and polities. The episode of conquest and colonization of the Americas began in the early 16th century, but was more difficult and lengthy than the conquest of the Aztecs and Incas. The last recognized Maya stronghold fell, at the Itza capital of Tayasal, in 1697.
ContentItems.Title: Yucatan Conquest

Exhibits.Title: Falling of the last recognized Maya stronghold

ContentItems.Caption: Teotihuancn was an ancient Mayan city founded around 100 BCE that continued to be built until 250 CE. For hundreds of years the city was the cultural, religious, and trading center of the Mayan Civilization. The city is thought to have lasted until the 7th and 8th centuries. The city began to come to an end in 869 and was fully abandoned in 899. The largest pyramid, the Pyramid of the Sun, was completed by 100AD. Today, the city is considered an archaeological site that contains the largest pyramidal structures built in the pre-columbian Americas.
ContentItems.Title: View From The Pyramid of the Sun at Teotihuancn

ContentItems.Caption: The Mayan writing system was developed around 300 BCE and continuously used until the arrival of the Spanish in the 16th century. The writing system is considered one of the most visually striking writing systems in the world. It is very complex, with hundreds of unique signs in the forms of humans, animals, objects, and abstract design. These signs are either logograms used to express meaning or syllabograms used to denote sound. This is an example of Mayan glyphs carved into stucco displayed at a museum in Palenque, Mexico.
ContentItems.Title: The Mayan Writing System

ContentItems.Caption: December 21, 2012, marks the end of a b'ak'tun, a period of 5,125 years based on the hierarchical modified base-twenty counting system of the Maya Long Count calendar. Some people and groups have interpreted this day to be associated with transformative, or possibly cataclysmic events, ranging from the start of a new era to the coming of the Apocalypse. Scholars have generally dismissed these interpretations as misguided, citing lack of evidence in recorded Mayan history for this date being significant at all other than marking the end of a relatively long cycle.
ContentItems.Title: Did the Mayans predict the end of the world?

ContentItems.Caption: This video provides a helpful visual representation explaining the Mayan calendar and its various counts. The calendar round is made up of three interlocking cycles, a 365 day solar year, a cycle of 20 names, and  a cycle of 30 numbers. Days are designated by the way these three cycles line up. 52 years will pass before the same 3 cycles line up again.
ContentItems.Title: Explaining the Maya Calendar

ContentItems.Caption: Haab' is name given to the Maya version of the 365-day calendar, which was common to many Pre-Columbian Mesoamerica cultures. Approximating the solar year, the Haab' was divided into 18 months of 20 days each and culminated with an additional five 'nameless' days, known as Wayeb'. Estimated to have been first used around 500 BCE, the Haab' created the basis for the Mayan agrarian cycle, and the months were based on the seasons and agricultural or climatological phenomena. Pictured above is a glyph representing Pax , the 16th month of Haab'. Pax and its glyph are associated with the time for planting crops.
ContentItems.Title: Haab'

ContentItems.Attribution: Cyrus Thomas (1904) Mayan calendar Systems II
ContentItems.Caption: When combined, the 260-day Tzolk'in count and the 365-day Haab' count produce a 18980-day (52 Haab') cycle known as a Calendar Round. However, to keep track of periods of time longer than 52 solar years, the Maya used the Long Count system. The Long Count calendar uses a modified base-twenty counting system to identify and record days elapsed since the Mayan creation date of 4 Ahaw, 8 Kumk'u (the equivalent of August 11, 3114 BCE on the Gregorian calendar). The image above ilustrates glyphs representing the Mayan creation date, found at the Quirigu Mayan archaeological site in Guatemala.
ContentItems.Title: Long Count

ContentItems.Caption: The Maya calendar dates back to at least the 5th century BCE, and is perhaps the most-studied and best-understood calendar of the early Mesoamerican civilizations. Like other related Mesoamerican calendars, such as the Aztec and Zapotec, the Maya calendar consists of several cycles, or counts, of varying lengths. The 260-day count, known as "Tzolk'in" in Maya, was common to all Mesoamerican calendars. This was combined with the "Haab", a 365-day count based on the solar year. These two counts combined to form the Calendar Round, a synchronized cycle that lasted for 52 solar years.
ContentItems.Title: Maya Calendar

ContentItems.Caption: "Tzolk'in" is the name given to the Maya 260-day calendar, also known as the Sacred Round. This is a ritual calendar, with no apparent correspondence to astronomical or agricultural cycles. The Tzolk'in combines a cycle of 20 named days with another count of thirteen numbers, producing 260 unique days. Each named day is associated with a natural object or phenomena. The Mayan glyph for "Imix", the first named day of the Tzolk'in calendar, is shown above. Imix is associated with the Crocodile, representing the "reptilian body" of the Earth.
ContentItems.Title: Tzolk'in

ContentItems.Caption: An archaeologist with help from the National Geographic Society discovers a never-before-seen Maya calendar in Guatemala that may dispel the myth predicting end times in 2012. It's the first glimpse of what science was like before the arrival of the Spanish, at the height of the Mayan civilization. Evidence was provided that even the Mayan themselves were not hemmed in by such a finite conception of time.
ContentItems.Title: Video: Doomsday Delayed? New Maya Calendar Unearthed

ContentItems.Caption: Kaminaljuyu is a Pre-Columbian site of the Maya civilization that was primarily occupied from 1500 BC to AD 1200. It has been described as one of the greatest of all archaeological sites in the New World, although its remains today are far less impressive. It was comprised of some 200 platforms and pyramidal mounds, half of which were created before the end of the Preclassic period.
ContentItems.Title: Monument 65, Kaminaljuyu, Guatemala

ContentItems.Caption: On November 23, as crowds gathered for the annual candlelight vigil in memory of assassinated City Supervisory Harvey Milk and San Francisco Mayor Edward Muscone, San Franciscans are urged to write the name of a loved one lost to AIDS on a poster board and carry it with them as they marched. Many are too scared but others write the names: Mark, Roger, David  Later that night, those few dozen poster boards are plastered on the front of the Old Federal Building and become the inspiration for The AIDS Memorial Quilt.
ContentItems.Title: Candlelight Vigil for Harvey Milk

ContentItems.Caption: The NAMES Foundation project was established in 1987. Their mission is to preserve, care for, and use the AIDS Memorial Quilt to foster healing, heighten awareness, and inspire action in the struggle against HIV and AIDS.
ContentItems.Title: The NAMES Foundation Project is Established

ContentItems.Caption:
In August, the first Quilt panel arrives for Rock Hudson. In a matter of days, Rock Hudsons panel, along with 40 others, are featured in a 40-foot high front window of Neiman Marcus in San Francisco. 

Rock Hudson is remembered with 16 Quilt panels including one on Block #1009, created by Jason Derer, with the help of his Aunt Doris Day.
ContentItems.Title: Rock Hudson's Panel Displayed in San Francisco

ContentItems.Caption: On October 11, 1987 the Quilt was displayed during the National March on Washington For Lesbian and Gay Rights.  It covered a space larger than a football field and included 1,920 quilt panels.
ContentItems.Title: First Display of the AIDS Memorial Quilt on the National Mall

ContentItems.Caption:
Cleve Jones and Joseph Durant create the first panels for The AIDS Memorial Quilt. The panels measure 3 feet by six feet, roughly the size of a human grave.

On October 11, the first National Display of The Quilt is presented on the Mall in Washington, D.C. and includes 1,920 panels. 

This display transforms statistics into souls and ignites a national conversation on HIV/AIDS.
ContentItems.Title: From Statistics to Souls

ContentItems.Caption:
The Quilt is a masterpiece. It is a rare and intense experience of what it means to be human. 

 Dame Elizabeth Taylor
ContentItems.Title: Elizabeth Taylor: Actress and International AIDS Activist

ContentItems.Caption: On June 28, to prepare for the first display of The Quilt, volunteers decide to stitch eight individual panels together to create the first block of The Quilt. Those first 44 Quilt panels are sewn into five blocks, which are hung from the Mayors Balcony in San Francisco as part of Gay Pride. The four remaining single panels are also displayed as part of an informational table.
ContentItems.Title: Panels Sewn into Blocks

ContentItems.Caption:
We thought wed close the doors after the first year. I even wrote my name and address on the first two panels I made because I wanted them back. 

 Gert McMullin
ContentItems.Title: Gert McMullin: Quilt Production Manager and 25 Year Quilt Veteran

ContentItems.Caption: In June, the first Quilt Workshop opens at 2362 Market Street in San Franciscos Castro Neighborhood. The panel for Reggie Hightower arrives from Atlanta. This is the first panel for someone outside San Francisco and it is the first indication that this Quilt is destined to be a national memorial.
ContentItems.Title: Beginning of a National Memorial

ContentItems.Caption: In October, a second national display of The Quilt is presented on the Ellipse in Washington, D.C. 8,288 panels on display.
ContentItems.Title: Panels on Display in Washington

ContentItems.Caption:
From April to July, seven volunteers load The Quilt, all 3500 panels, into a 30-foot white truck the group names Stella. For the next four months, they zig-zag across the country, displaying The Quilt in communities where volunteers step forward and free venues can be secured. Individuals who follow The Quilt from city to city are nicknamed Thread Heads. The tour raises $500,000 for hundreds of AIDS service organizations. More than 9,000 volunteers across the US help the seven-person traveling crew move and display The Quilt. 

In the summer, Dr. Jonathan Mann, founding director of World Health Organizations Global Program on AIDS, orchestrates a European tour of The Quilt to unite the worlds response to the pandemic and to establish a worldwide ritual to be called World AIDS Day.
ContentItems.Title: The Quilt Tours the U.S. and Europe

ContentItems.Caption: In October 1988, at the end of its first tour of major US cities, The Quilt was once again laid out on the National Mall.  By this date, the quilt had grown to 8,288 panels.  Celebrities, politicians, families, lovers, and friends read aloud the names of people represented on quilt panels.  The reading of names is not a tradition at every Quilt display.
ContentItems.Title: The Quilt Grows

ContentItems.Caption: Common Threads: Stories From The Quilt wins the Academy Award as the best feature-length documentary film.
ContentItems.Title: The Quilt on Film

ContentItems.Caption: A second tour of North America brings The Quilt to 19 additional cities in the U.S. and Canada.
ContentItems.Title: Second American Tour

ContentItems.Caption: The Quilt now includes panels from every state and 28 countries. At the end of 1989, The Quilt is composed of 10,088 panels.
ContentItems.Title: An International Memorial

ContentItems.Caption: The AIDS Memorial Quilt is nominated for a Nobel Peace Prize.
ContentItems.Title: Quilt Nominated for Nobel Peace Prize

ContentItems.Caption: The NAMES Project returns to the nations Capital for a third time with the entire AIDS Memorial Quilt, this time in the shadow of the Washington Monument. To reflect the global nature of the AIDS pandemic, this display was titled the International Display..
ContentItems.Title: Third Laying of the Quilt in Washington

ContentItems.Caption: Designers in the U.S. and England join forces to create a series of quilt panels remembering those lost by the fashion industry.
ContentItems.Title: The Fashion Industry Remembered in the Quilt

ContentItems.Caption:
President Clintons inaugural parade. Over 200 volunteers, including representatives of national AIDS organizations and Leanza Cornett, Miss America 1993, carry Quilt panels down Pennsylvania Avenue.

Forever remembered on The Quilt: Rudolph Nureyev, Michael Bennett, Robert Mapplethorpe, Freddie Mercury, Perry Ellis, Tony Perkins, Liberace, Keith Haring, Howard Ashman, Halston, Michael Foucault
ContentItems.Title: The Quilt Featured in Clinton's Inaugural Parade

ContentItems.Caption: NAMES Project begins the National Interfaith Program to bring The Quilt to places of worship and to spiritual communities.
ContentItems.Title: National Interfaith Program

ContentItems.Caption:
Seven hundred Quilt panels from 35 countries are displayed in San Francisco as part of events commemorating the 50th anniversary of the founding of the United Nations.

In San Francisco, the staff must sew 10,000 new panels into blocks for the upcoming national D.C. display. The staff sews 20 hours a day, doing 10-hour shifts. The volunteers that sew all night are called QUILT ZOMBIES. The staff also recruits volunteers from around the country to teach them how to bundle The Quilt, to edge, and grommet. 

After training in San Francisco, the volunteers return home to set-up sewing circles and The Quilt is literally stitched together in communities from coast to coast.Toward the front, a woman at a sewing machine finished hemming a panel and folded it, carefully keeping the name face down. If I look at the names, I get sentimental, she said, So I dont look, I just work.
ContentItems.Title: Sewing the Quilt Together

ContentItems.Caption: NAMES Project launches the National High School Quilt Program, a project that opens the doors to HIV prevention education in the school system.
ContentItems.Title: National High School Quilt Program

ContentItems.Caption: The last time the Quilt was laid out in its entirety, it covered the National Mall, with 47,000 panels.  Since 1987 more than 14 million people have visited the Quilt at thousands of displays worldwide.
ContentItems.Title: The Quilt Covers the National Mall

ContentItems.Caption:
In October, the entire Quilt  40,000 panels  is displayed on the National Mall in Washington, D.C. An estimated 1.2 million people visit. Covering the National Mall from the Washington Monument to the grounds of the U.S. Capital Building, The Quilt occupied an area equal to 24 football fields.

President William J. Clinton attends the national Quilt display on the Mall, along with First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton. He is the first U.S. President to visit a display of The AIDS Memorial Quilt.

I remember when Hillary and I walked on the Mall to see The Quilt.
