It was a personally emotional thing, seeing the love and devotion that those sections of The Quilt represented for all those people who died prematurely, and knowing that now, with medicine, they didnt have to die so fast anymore, if we did the right things. It was a very emotional day.  President William J. Clinton
ContentItems.Title: Fourth Laying of the Quilt in Washington D.C.

ContentItems.Caption:
The NAMES Project Foundation moves national headquarters to Atlanta. The cross-country move was made to shore up the Foundations finances and to be in a better position to address the changing face of HIV/AIDS.

Civil Rights legend and Congressman John Lewis offers remarks at dedication ceremony.
ContentItems.Title: New Home for the NAMES Project

ContentItems.Caption: In December, the NAMES Project orchestrates more than 300 World AIDS Day displays of the Quilt and brings more than a million Americans face to face with this American treasure.
ContentItems.Title: World AIDS Day Displays

ContentItems.Caption: Call My Name Panelmaking Program is launched in Atlanta to encourage communities of color to create new panels for loved ones lost to AIDS.
ContentItems.Title: "Call My Name"

ContentItems.Caption: The Quilt is featured alongside Billy Howards photography exhibit, Epitaphs for the Living in the Very Special Arts of Georgia Gallery.
ContentItems.Title: "Epitaphs for the Living"

ContentItems.Caption: June 25, The NAMES Project returns to Washington, D.C. to display the 1000 newest Quilt blocks on The Ellipse
ContentItems.Title: NAMES Project Returns to Washington, D.C.

ContentItems.Caption:
In October, The AIDS Memorial Quilt is declared an official American Treasure under the Save Americas Treasures Act  recognizing The Quilt as part of Americas priceless historic legacy and one that helps explain Americas past to future generations.

These treasures mark historic and continuing struggles to define, extend and uphold the nations founding ideals of freedom and equality. 
 Brent D. Glass, former Director, National Museum of American History
ContentItems.Title: The Quilt Is Declared an American Treasure

ContentItems.Caption: The panel for AIDS Activist Roger Lyon becomes part of an exhibition titled, Smithsonian Treasures of American History and is displayed alongside the Greensboro lunch counter where students protested racial segregation.
ContentItems.Title: Activist Roger Lyon's Panel Featured in an Exhibit

ContentItems.Caption: In June and July, The Quilt is presented with the exhibition, Beautiful Things: A Showcase of South African Craft as part of the National Black Arts Festival in Atlanta.
ContentItems.Title: The Quilt at the National Black Arts Festival

ContentItems.Caption:
The Quilt is featured at the opening ceremonies of the Gay Games in Chicago. 

Founder of the Gay Games, Dr. Tom Waddell, who was an Olympic athlete, is remembered with several panels including one on Block #687.

Through its evolution, The Quilt evolved as a powerful tool for social change. In 1987 when the first panel of The Quilt was constructed, public officials were debating mandatory testing and mandatory quarantines of infected citizens. Homophobic reaction to HIV/AIDS was rampant. First dubbed the Gay Plague and the disease of drug addicts, HIV/AIDS was a companion to prejudice and ignorance. The Quilt became a unifying force both for the gay community and for society. Quilt tours became a venue for peaceful demonstration; an opportunity for all people to stand together and honor those lost to AIDS and a means to support the gay community.
ContentItems.Title: The Quilt and the LGBT Community

ContentItems.Caption: From February to April, Andrea Bowers exhibition, The Weight of Relevance is on display at Secession in Vienna, Austria. The celebrated artist had previously spent more than a month with The NAMES Project for her Quilt based exhibition.
ContentItems.Title: Artists Inspired by the Quilt

ContentItems.Attribution: Kezia L. Ellison's Service Learning Project
ContentItems.Caption: In December, More than 75 teens create HIV/AIDS awareness panels that are displayed with The Quilt at a World AIDS Day event at The Olivet Boys & Girls Club. Kevin Devera, leader of the club, dedicates a new panel in memory of his brother, Rick.
ContentItems.Title: The Quilt and Teen AIDS Awareness

ContentItems.Caption:
In March, 100 new Quilt panels are begun in Atlanta in conjunction with the National Week of Prayer for the Healing of AIDS  seven panelmaking workshops are held in seven days. These workshops are a part of the Call My Name panelmaking program, that invites communities of color to create new panels to memorialize loved ones lost to AIDS.

As part of this commemoration, Rev. Raphael Warnock, the Senior Pastor of Historic Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta, takes an HIV/AIDS test during the Sunday morning service to encourage members to do the same. 

We dont like to talk about these things in church. Weve got to fight the unholy trinity of silence, shame and stigma. As Reverend Warnock makes these remarks, he stands in front of four blocks of The Quilt.
ContentItems.Title: National Week of Prayer for the Healing of AIDS

ContentItems.Caption: In December, MetroHealth System in Cleveland, Ohio presents Art, Activism & AIDS  a panel-making program that pairs panelmakers with art students and sewing specialists. Presented with a display of the Quilt.
ContentItems.Title: Panelmakers Collaborate with Art Students

ContentItems.Caption:
World AIDS Day  Emory University hosts 100 Quilt blocks, making it the largest Quilt display on any 
college campus.
ContentItems.Title: Campus Display

ContentItems.Caption: In August, the NAMES Project partners with Dreamgirls Sheryl Lee Ralph to raise awareness and inspire the creation of new panels for members of the African American community. Ralph co-hosts a Call My Name panelmaking workshop on the Spelman College campus in Atlanta.
ContentItems.Title: Sheryl Lee Ralph Partners with the NAMES Project

ContentItems.Caption: Twenty years ago a man came to the San Francisco workshop to drop off a new Quilt panel. This 3-foot-by-6-foot panel included no name, no photographs, no birth or death dates. Instead, this panel was a call to action, a quiet prayer, a stark reminder of what we are all working to achieve.We asked if we could hold on to this panel and only sewn into The AIDS Memorial Quilt when it was truly, the last one. With each Quilt display, each new panel, each scientific advancement, and each moment of recognition that AIDS is about all of us  we inch closer to realizing that goal.
ContentItems.Title: The Last One

ContentItems.Caption:
In June and July, the Quilt marks its 25 anniversary on the National Mall by participating in the Smithsonian Institutions 2012 Folklife Festival. The Festival program, titled Creativity and Crisis: Unfolding The AIDS Memorial Quilt, brings more than one million visitors face to face with The Quilt and includes an array of craft demonstrations, dance and musical performances, interactive discussions.

The Quilt is the premiere symbol of the AIDS pandemic and the largest piece of community art in the world  a living memorial to a generation lost to AIDS and our most potent HIV prevention education tool.
ContentItems.Title: The Quilt at the 2012 Folklife Festival

ContentItems.Caption:
Created by the Public Interactives Research Team at University of Southern
California:  Anne Balsamo (PI), Lauren Fenton, and Rosemary Comella.  In
collaboration with researchers at the University California Berkeley:  Roland
Saekow, Madison Allen.  Interactive Timeline powered by ChronoZoom, developed at the
University of California, Berkeley, Microsoft Research, and Moscow State University,
made possible by the Outercurve Foundation.
ContentItems.Title: AIDS History Interactive Timeline 1.0 Credits

ContentItems.Caption: There were many unofficial titles or descriptions of the cluster of diseases that were afflicting young gay men.  At one point the medical community considered the name GRID: which stood for Gay-related Immune Deficiency.  Another name was the 4-H syndrome, so named for the four groups of people who were mostly afflicted: homosexuals, hemophiliacs, heroine users, and Haitians.
ContentItems.Title: A disease not-yet named

ContentItems.Caption:
By 2011, scholars had a better understanding about how the initial chimpanzee virus traveled from Central Africa to the West.  Two books reported on the historical evidence that mapped the virus' migration; both books argue that colonialist practices enabled the spread of the disease.
Here a young man gets vaccinated against leprosy in Nigeria in the 1950s.
ContentItems.Title: How the initial infection traveled

ContentItems.Caption: Between 1884 and 1924, somewhere near modern-day Kinshasa in West Central Africa, a hunter kills a chimpanzee. Some of the animal's blood enters the hunter's body, possibly through an open wound. The blood carries a virus harmless to the chimp but lethal to humans: HIV. The virus spreads as colonial cities sprout up, but the deaths are blamed on other causes.
ContentItems.Title: From monkeys to humans

ContentItems.Caption:
In June, the Center for Disease Control (CDC) in the US publishes a report about
five young homosexual men with life-threatening PCP pneumonia.  In July, the CDC
reports that an unusual skin cancer -- Kaposi's sarcoma -- is killing young,
previously healthy men in New York City and California.  These symptoms would later
become recognized as "opportunistic diseases" associated with HIV infection. By
year-end, there is a cumulative total of 270 reported cases of severe immune
deficiency among gay men, and 121 fatalities. The above photograph depicts a man
with Kaposi's Sarcoma, a rare cancer that afflicted many gay men in the early days
of what would become known as AIDS.
ContentItems.Title: Surprising increase in deaths among young men

ContentItems.Caption:
The CDC calls the new disease:  Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome or AIDS. The CDC
estimates that tens of thousands of people may be affected by the disease.
ContentItems.Title: "AIDS"

ContentItems.Caption: On December 10, CDC reports a case of AIDS in an infant who received blood transfusions. The following week, the Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report (MMWR) reports 22 cases of unexplained immunodeficiency and opportunistic infections in infants.
ContentItems.Title: First Infant Cases Reported

ContentItems.Caption:
Gay Mens Health Crisis, the first community-based AIDS service provider in the U.S., is founded in New York City.
In January, the first AIDS clinic in the United States is established in San Francisco.
ContentItems.Title: First Community Care Providers

ContentItems.Caption:
In April , U.S. Representative Henry Waxman convenes the first congressional
hearings on HIV/AIDS. In this photograph, three AIDS activists are sworn in before a
House Governmental Relations subcommittee hearing on Capitol Hill to study
strategies for dealing with the fatal disease.  Left to right: Michael Callen (New
York), Roger Lyon (San Francisco), and Anthony Ferrara (Washington).
ContentItems.Title: First Congressional hearings

ContentItems.Caption: AIDS is seen in people with hemophilia, convincing scientists that the disease is spread by an infectious agent in contaminated blood.
ContentItems.Title: First Hemophiliac Cases Reported

ContentItems.Caption: People living with AIDS (PLWAs) take over the plenary stage at the Second National AIDS Forum in Denver, and issue a statement on the right of PLWAs to be at the table when policy is made, to be treated with dignity, and to be called people with AIDS, not AIDS victims. The statement becomes known as The Denver Principles, and it serves as the charter for the founding of the National Association of People with AIDS  (NAPWA).
ContentItems.Title: Activism for PLWAs' rights

ContentItems.Caption: The heterosexual spread of AIDS in Africa is confirmed.
ContentItems.Title: Epidemic in Africa

ContentItems.Caption:
In a September  publication, the CDC identifies the major routes of HIV
transmission, and rules out transmission by casual contact, food, water, air, or
environmental surfaces. The CDC offers the initial warning that AIDS may spread by
heterosexual sex and by mother-to-child transmission.
ContentItems.Title: Transmission Mode Identified

ContentItems.Caption:
Public apprehension spreads based on lack of knowledge and incomplete communication
from government health officials. Rumors circulate of "household spread" -- the
belief that simply sharing living space with someone who is infected with HIV can
lead to infection. In New York, some landlords start to evict PLWAs (people living
with AIDS).
ContentItems.Title: Fear and Misunderstanding Spread

ContentItems.Caption:
Pasteur Institute researchers Luc Montagnier and Francoise Barre-Sinoussi isolate a
virus from the swollen lymph gland of a person with AIDS. They called it
lymphadenopathy-associated virus or LAV. Independently, Jay Levy, a researcher at
the University of California, San Francisco isolates a virus called AIDS-related
virus or ARV.  It isn't until 1986 that the medical community agrees to call the
virus human immunodeficiency virus or HIV.
ContentItems.Title: Identification of HIV

ContentItems.Caption:
The American Foundation for AIDS Research (amFAR) is founded to raise funds from
private sources to support medical research on HIV/AIDS.  Elizabeth Taylor becomes
the Foundation's spokeswoman. A scathing government report blasts the United States
Department of Health and Human Services for not providing adequate funds for medical
research on HIV/AIDS.
ContentItems.Title: Foundation Established to Raise Research Funds

ContentItems.Caption:
In 1985, the First International AIDS Conference is held in Atlanta. By this date,
every region of the world reports at least one HIV case.
ContentItems.Title: First International AIDS Conference

ContentItems.Caption:
The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) licenses the first commercial blood test,
ELISA, that detect antibodies to HIV.  For the first time, blood banks begin
screening the US blood supply.
ContentItems.Title: First Commercial Blood Test Available

ContentItems.Caption:
The Secretary of the US Department of Health and Human Services, announces that
Robert Gallo and his colleagues at the National Cancer Institute have isolated the
cause of AIDS:  the retrovirus HTLV-III.   Also announced is the development of a
diagnostic blood test to identify HTLV-III.  Many people express hope that a vaccine
against AIDS will be produced within two years.
ContentItems.Title: Retrovirus Identified

ContentItems.Caption:
In 1986, as AIDS hysteria builds through the US, Ryan White, an Indiana teenager who
contracted AIDS through contaminated blood products used to treat his hemophilia, is
barred from school.  He sued for the right to return to school; this photograph
shows him after the announcement that he could go back to classes.
ContentItems.Title: Ryan White Barred From School

ContentItems.Caption:
Rock Hudson is one of the first major Hollywood stars to die of AIDS-related
complications. At first, the popular media reported that he had liver cancer, but he
later admitted that his illness was due to AIDS. This disclosure not only revealed
his homosexuality but had an immediate impact on the visibility of AIDS among the
general US population.  This recognition spurred increases in funding for medical
research related to the disease.
ContentItems.Title: Rock Hudson Dies of AIDS

ContentItems.Caption:
The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approves the first antiretroviral drug,
zidovudine, commonly referred to as AZT.  The activist group called AIDS Coalition
to Unleash Power (ACT-UP) forms to protest the $10,000 per year cost of the AZT
treatment. It adopts the motto:  SILENCE=DEATH. The US Congress approves $30 million
in emergency funding to states to subsidize the purchase of AZT for people who are
infected with HIV.  This lays the groundwork for what will known as the AIDS Drug
Assistance Program (ADAP) that is authorized by the Ryan White CARE Act in 1990.
ContentItems.Title: ACT-UP  Protests Cost of AZT

ContentItems.Caption:
Princess Diana makes international headlines by embracing AIDS patients in the UK. 
In response to the outrage, she states:  "HIV does not make people dangerous to
know, so you can shake their hands or give them a hug. Heaven knows they need it.
In her work with an international AIDS charity, she was one of  first public figures
in Britain to attempt to stop the stigmatization of AIDS patients.
ContentItems.Title: AIDS as an International Cause

ContentItems.Caption:
After Floridas Desoto County School Board refuses to allow HIV-positive brothers,
Ricky, Robert, and Randy Ray to attend school, a Federal judge orders the board to
reinstate the three hemophiliacs, who contracted HIV through contaminated blood
products. After the August ruling, outraged town residents refuse to allow their
children to attend school, and someone sets fire to the Ray house on August 28,
destroying it.
ContentItems.Title: Ray Brothers Ruling

ContentItems.Caption:
For the first time, President Reagan makes a speech about AIDS. Although AIDS was
first identified in 1981, Reagan did not mention it publicly for several years until
a press conference he gave in 1985.
ContentItems.Title: First Public Acknowledgement by US President

ContentItems.Caption:
The US forbids immigration by people infected with HIV. Under legislation enacted by
the US Congress in 1993, people found importing anti-HIV medication into the country
were arrested and immediately deported back to their country of origin.
ContentItems.Title: US Immigration Ban

ContentItems.Caption:
American photographer, Robert Mapplethorpe, dies from AIDS at the age of 42. His
work was controversial at the time for its homoerotic content, and consequently
provoked heated debate over the public funding of art. Thi  self-portrait was made
in 1988, a year before his death.
ContentItems.Title: Photographer Robert Mapplethorpe Dies of AIDS

ContentItems.Caption:
The Joint United Nations Programm on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS) reports that the number of
women living with HIV/AIDS in sub-Saharan Africa exceeds that of men.
ContentItems.Title: Increasing Numbers of Women Infected with HIV

ContentItems.Caption:
The number of reported AIDS cases in the United States reaches 100,000.
ACT UP protests shut down the FDA. Within a week, the FDA begins a "fast-track" policy allowing public access to lifesaving drugs still in clinical trials.
ContentItems.Title: 100,000 Afflicted

ContentItems.Caption:
Under the direction of the Surgeon General of the US, C. Everette Koop, a pamphlet
titled "Understanding AIDS" was mailed to every household in the US: 107 million
copies. As he wrote in the original report: "We are fighting a disease, not people."
This pamphlet and Koop's prior longer report on HIV infection was an attempt to
shift the US national dialogue about AIDS from a focus on identity (homosexuality)
to a discussion of safer sex practices.
ContentItems.Title: Message from the US Surgeon General

ContentItems.Caption:
Scientists determine that even before AIDS symptoms develop, HIV replicates wildly
in the blood. The goal of treatment shifts to keeping HIV at low levels.  The term
"T-Cells" enters into popular conversation.
ContentItems.Title: New Approach to Treatment

ContentItems.Attribution: The Single Girl's Guide To Men
ContentItems.Caption:
The first World AIDS Day is held on Dec. 1, 1988.  The event was first conceived in
August 1987 by James W. Bunn and Thomas Netter, two public information officers for
the Global Program on AIDS at the World Health Organization in Geneva, Switzerland. 
Their objective was to use the day to publicize the rate of HIV/AIDS infection
around the globe and to promote educational efforts to stop the spread of HIV.
ContentItems.Title: First World AIDS Day

ContentItems.Caption: The red ribbon, designed by the New York-based Visual AIDS Artists Caucus, is introduced as an international symbol of AIDS solidarity. According to Frank Moore of Visual AIDS, the color red was chosen for its "connection to blood and the idea of passion - not only anger, but love, like a valentine."
ContentItems.Title: An International Symbol

ContentItems.Caption:
American basketball star Earvin Magic Johnson announces that he is HIV-positive.
The lead singer for the British rock band Queen, Freddy Mercury, dies of AIDS.
ContentItems.Title: Celebrities with AIDS

ContentItems.Caption: According to the CDC, deaths caused by HIV infection were the third leading cause of death among persons aged 25-44 years. The death rate for HIV infection for men of this age group was seven times that for women.  After 1995, the rates started increasing for women, by 1996, the rate of death in women from HIV became much higher than the death rate for men.
ContentItems.Title: Leading cause of death for US men 25-44 years old

ContentItems.Caption: The previous year, ACT UP protests at the National Institutes of Health (NIH), demanding the expansion of clinical trials to include more women and people of color.
ContentItems.Title: Demand for More Representative Clinical Trials

ContentItems.Caption: The CDC launches the first condom ads to air on US television.  The photograph above shows a CDC safe sex campaign poster from 1989.
ContentItems.Title: Safe Sex Campaign on TV

ContentItems.Caption:
The CDC adds three new conditionspulmonary tuberculosis, recurrent pneumonia, and
invasive cervical cancerto the list of clinical indicators of AIDS. The inclusion
of these new conditions mean that more women and injection drug users will be
diagnosed with AIDS.
ContentItems.Title: Diagnosis Criteria Encompasses Wider Demographic

ContentItems.Caption: The activist group ACT-UP and Benetton put a giant condom on the Place de Concorde in Paris.
ContentItems.Title: International Awareness Campaign

ContentItems.Caption: Angels in America, Tony Kushners play about AIDS, wins the Tony Award for Best Play and the 1993 Pulitzer Prize for Drama.
ContentItems.Title: AIDS and the Arts

ContentItems.Caption: Pedro Zamora, a young gay man living with HIV, appears on the cast of MTVs popular show, The Real World. One day after the season finale, he dies at the age of 22.
ContentItems.Title: AIDS on Television

ContentItems.Caption: AIDS is the leading cause of death for all Americans ages 25 to 44. While the demand for treatment has never been higher, medical researchers are unable to develop more effective drugs.  The search for a vaccine continues to elude the efforts of medical researchers.
ContentItems.Title: Facing AIDS

ContentItems.Caption:
Medical researchers develop a new treatment approach referred to as an AIDS drug
"cocktail".  It consists of a combination of drugs.  Called highly active
anti-retroviral therapy or HAART, the treatment can cut HIV viral load to
undetectable levels.  Hope surges when AIDS researcher David Ho, MD, suggests
treatment could eliminate HIV from the body.  He's wrong -- it's later found that
HIV hides in dormant cells.  In one year, deaths from AIDS in the US decline by more
than 40%.
ContentItems.Title: HAART

ContentItems.Caption:
UN Secretary General Kofi Annan proposes the Global Fund to Fight HIV/AIDS, TB and
Malaria. The purpose of the Global Fund is to mobilize, manage, and distribute funds
to fight the pandemic of infectious diseases. Treatment is still totally unavailable
to the vast majority of people living with HIV throughout the globe. Only 1% of the
4.1 million sub-Saharan Africans with HIV receive anti-HIV drugs.  The above
photograph show an aerial view of a graveyard in South Africa, where 250,000 died of
AIDS in a single year.
ContentItems.Title: Developing Nations Demand Access to Treatment

ContentItems.Caption: AIDS becomes the leading cause of death worldwide for people aged 15 to 59.
ContentItems.Title: Know Your Status

ContentItems.Caption: In 2000, President Clinton issues an Executive Order to assist developing countries in importing and producing generic HIV treatments.
ContentItems.Title: International Outreach

ContentItems.Caption: In 2003, President Bush announces the $15 billion President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief. The prevention portion of the plan is criticized for over-emphasis on abstinence. But the plan provides much-needed HIV/AIDS-treatment funds to 15 nations.
ContentItems.Title: PEPFAR

ContentItems.Caption: The 14th International AIDS Conference is held in Barcelona, Spain in 2002. Dozens of countries report they are experiencing serious HIV/AIDS epidemics, and many more are on the brink.
ContentItems.Title: The Epidemic Becomes a Pandemic

ContentItems.Caption:
After generic drug manufacturers agree to produce discounted, generic forms of
HIV/AIDS drugs for developing countries, several major pharmaceutical manufacturers
also agree reduce drug prices to those countries.  The Joint United Nations Program
on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS), along with the World Health Organization (WHO), and other
global health groups announce a joint initiative with five major pharmaceutical
manufacturers to negotiate reduced prices for HIV/AIDS drugs in developing
countries.
ContentItems.Title: Generic AIDS Drugs Reach the World Market

ContentItems.Caption:
Awareness grows that HAART has serious side effects. Increasing evidence of drug resistance also calls into question the hit early, hit hard strategy.

In the ensuing years, the FDA approves new classes of drugs that make HIV treatment safer, easier, and more effective. But the drugs still do not cure AIDS.
ContentItems.Title: Beyond HAART

ContentItems.Caption:
UNAIDS calculates that the global spread of AIDS peaked in 1996 at 3.5 million new
infections. Deaths peaked in 2004, at 2.2 million.  But by 2009, the figures are
still grim:  2.7 million new HIV infections and 2 million AIDS deaths in 2008.  Half
of those who need it get no treatment.  Polls show most Americans no longer consider
AIDS a major problem.  They're wrong.   African Americans -- 12% of the U.S.
population -- get 45% of new HIV infections.
ContentItems.Title: Still an Epidemic, Many Untreated

ContentItems.Caption: Luc Montagnier and Francoise Barre-Sinoussi awarded Nobel Prize in medicine for discovery of HIV.
ContentItems.Title: Nobel Prize Awarded

ContentItems.Caption:
US President Barack Obama announces that his administration will officially lift the
HIV travel and immigration ban in January 2010. The lifting of the travel ban occurs
in conjunction with the announcement that the International AIDS Conference will
return to the United States in 2012 for the first time in more than 20 years.
ContentItems.Title: Lift of Immigration Ban

ContentItems.Caption: In 2009, black women accounted for 30% of new HIV infections among all blacks in the US.  Estimated rate of new HIV infections for black women was more than 15 times as high as the rate for white women, and more that three times as high as that of Latina women.
ContentItems.Title: African-American Women at Highest Risk

ContentItems.Caption: Of the 33 million people now living with HIV, 3 million are getting treatment. That's less than a third of those who need immediate treatment. Yet for the first time, global AIDS deaths decline.
ContentItems.Title: Global AIDS Deaths Decline

ContentItems.Caption: Health officials report that Washington, DC has a higher rate of HIV (3% prevalence) than West Africa  enough to describe it as a severe and generalized epidemic. The White House and the CDC launch the Act Against AIDS campaign, a communication campaign designed to reduce HIV incidence in the United States. The CDC also launches the Act Against AIDS Leadership Initiative (AAALI), to harness the collective strength and reach of traditional, longstanding African American institutions to increase awareness, knowledge, and action within Black communities across the U.S.
ContentItems.Title: Addressing Communities

ContentItems.Caption: Medical researchers have identified more than a dozen antibodies that target the HIV virus.  This provides hope that they can create a vaccine that offers long-term protection against AIDS. One antibody in particular, PGT 128, is considered among the most potent and promising.  In laboratory tests, it is shown to prevent 70% of viruses from infecting cells. This HIV-neutralizing antibody may lead to new vaccines.
ContentItems.Title: Hope for a Vaccine

ContentItems.Caption:
In June 2011 3,000 people participate in the United Nations (UN) High-Level Meeting
on HIV/AIDS in New York. The session recognizes critical milestones, including three
decades of the pandemic and the 10-year anniversary of the 2001 UN General Assembly
Special Session on HIV/AIDS and the resulting Declaration of Commitment. At the
Meeting, the U.S. joined with other partners in launching a global plan to eliminate
mother-to-child transmission of HIV and keep mothers alive.
ContentItems.Title: Global Plan to End Mother-to-Child Transmission

ContentItems.Caption:
On September 30, the first Road to AIDS 2012 Town Hall meeting kicks off in San
Francisco. This is the first of 15 meetings to be held across the country, leading
up to the XIX International AIDS Conference (AIDS 2012), to be held July 22-27,
2012, in Washington, DC.
ContentItems.Title: Road to AIDS 2012

ContentItems.Caption:
Created by the Public Interactives Research Team at University of Southern
California:  Anne Balsamo (PI), Lauren Fenton, and Rosemary Comella.  In
collaboration with researchers at the University California Berkeley:  Roland
Saekow, Madison Allen.  Interactive Timeline powered by ChronoZoom, developed at the
University of California, Berkeley, Microsoft Research, and Moscow State University,
made possible by the Outercurve Foundation.
ContentItems.Title: AIDS History Interactive Timeline 1.0 Credits

ContentItems.Caption: The Great Sphinx of Giza is a limestone statue of a reclining mythical creature with a lion's body and a human head that stands on the Giza Plateau in Egypt. It is the largest monolith statue in the world and the oldest known monumental sculpture. It is believed to have been built by ancient Egyptians of the Old Kingdom during the reign of the pharaoh Khafra. In this picture, Jean-Leon Gerome depicts Napoleon Bonaparte before the Sphinx.
ContentItems.Title: Bonaparte Before the Sphinx

ContentItems.Caption: Oil on Canvas. Signed and dated. Inscribed in relining: "To Dr Henry Bence Jones/With the Artist's Best Wishes/July 14, 1862" Ancient Egyptian pyramids are ancient pyramid shaped masonry. Most of the 138 pyramids discovered were built as tombs for the country's pharaohs and their consorts.
ContentItems.Title: Egyptian Landscape with a Distant View of the Pyramids.

ContentItems.Attribution: scanned by Infrogmation from a 19th century stereopticon card photo in Infrogmation's own collection.
ContentItems.Caption: The Great Pyramid of Giza (Pyramid of Khufu) is the oldest and largest of the three pyramids in the Giza Necropolis. It is the oldest of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World, and the only one to remain largely intact. It was believed to be built as a tomb for fourth dynasty Egyptina Pharaoh Khufu over an approximate 20 year period, and stood as the tallest man-made structure in the world for over 3800 years.
ContentItems.Title: Great Pyramid of Giza

ContentItems.Caption: By the early dynastic period of Egyptian history, those with sufficient means were buried in mastabas. The architect Imhotep, who believed by Egyptologists believe to be a tomb for the pharaoh Djoser. Imhotep is credited to have conceived the notion of stacking mastabas on top of each other, creating an edifice composed of a number of "steps" that decreased in size towards its apex. The Step Pyramid of Djoser served as a gigantic stairway to the heavens that the diseased pharaoh could ascend to.
ContentItems.Title: Henry A. Bacon - 'Egyptian Pyramids', Watercolor Over Graphite

ContentItems.Attribution: Catalogue Gnral des Antiquits gyptiennes du Muse du Caire. Statuen und Statuetten von Knigen und Privatleuten. Teil 1
ContentItems.Caption: Statue of Khafre from his valley temple at Giza, now in the Egyptian Museum, Cairo. Khafre was a son of king Khufu and the brother and successor of Djedefre. Khafre built the second largest pyramid at Giza. The sphinx is also said to date to the time of Khafre.
ContentItems.Title: Khafre

ContentItems.Caption: Statue of Khufu in the Cairo Egyptian Museum. Khufu was a  Pharaoh of Ancient Egypt's Old Kingdom. He reigned from around 2589 to 2566 BC, was the second pharaoh of the Fourth Dynasty, and the generally accepted builder of the Great Pyramid of Giza.
ContentItems.Title: Khufu

ContentItems.Caption: The hypothesis in pyramidology claims that the 3 largest pyramids of the Giza pyramid complex correlates to the three middle stars of the constellation Orion, and that this correlation was intended by the builders of the pyramids. The Orion was associated with Osiris, the god of rebirth adn afterlife, by ancient Egyptians. The theory was first put forward by Robert Bauval in 1983.
ContentItems.Title: Orion Correlation Theory

ContentItems.Attribution: Mirko ucur. SveMir (Sveltlana i Mirko). Own work.
ContentItems.Caption: The Pyramid of Khafre (Pyramid of Chefren) is the second largest of the ancient Egyptian Pyramids of Giza and the tomb of the fourth-dynasty pharaoh Khafre. The pyramid was built like the Great Pyramid built by Khafre's father Khufu. Khafre's reign lasted ca. 2650 BC - 2480 BC.
ContentItems.Title: Pyramid of Khafre

ContentItems.Caption: Unfinished stones at the base of the third pyramid of Menkaure. The pyramid is the smallest of the three Pyramids of Giza. It was built to serve as the tomb of the fourth dynasty Egyptian Pharaoh Menkaure. The pyramid was constructed of limestone and granite. Menkaure was allegedly a much more benevolent Pharaoh than his predecessors. However, the Gods ordained that Egypt should suffer tyrranical rulers for a hundred and fifty years. His wish was to prove the oracle false.
ContentItems.Title: Pyramid of Menkaure

ContentItems.Caption: The shape of Egyptian pyramids is thought to represent the primordial mound from which the Earth was created.Pyramids were believed to serve as a type of "resurrection machine," one which the pharaoh's could travel through one of the narrow shafts extending from the main burial chamber, through the body of the pyramid, towards the center part of the sky between the stars where Egyptians believed was the gateway to heaven.
ContentItems.Title: Pyramids of Gizeh

ContentItems.Caption: David Christian describes how global exchange networks, competitive markets and increasing use of energy have accelerated the pace of change in recent decades.
ContentItems.Title: Threshold 8: Origins of The Modern World - Part 1

ContentItems.Caption: We lead lives that even kings and emperors 500 years ago could only dream about, rapidly consuming Earths resources. Does our impact on the biosphere suggest weve entered a new geologic age, with new challenges of sustainability?
ContentItems.Title: Threshold 8: Origins of The Modern World - Part 2

ContentItems.Caption: The Waldseemller Map was the first map to include the name "America", and the first to depict the Americas as separate from Asia. It was created in 1507 and marks the beginning of the modern era. There is only one surviving copy of the map, which was purchased by the Library of Congress in 2001 for $10 million.
ContentItems.Title: Waldseemller Map

ContentItems.Caption: This colour-coded map made by the U.S. Department of Agriculture shows the relative population density of the globe in 1994. Darker red regions indicate greater population density, while green represents sparsely populated areas and grey means virtually uninhabited. As can be seen, populations tend to be most dense on coasts and near bodies of water, while very cold or dry areas like Northern Canada and the Sahara Desert are more or less uninhabited.
ContentItems.Title: World Population Density, 1994

References.Publication: The British Journal for the History of Science
References.Title: De-centring the big picture: The Origins of Modern Science and the modern origins of science
Origins of the Modern World System: A Missing Link

Exhibits.Title: Threshold 8: Origins of The Modern World

ContentItems.Attribution: The General Libraries, The University of Texas at Austin
ContentItems.Caption: The Ottoman Empire was one of the largest and longest lasting empires in history, existing from 1299 to 1923. Under the reign of Suleiman the Magnificent, the empire became the most powerful state in the world, a multinational, multilingual empire controlling much of southeast Europe, western Asia, and North Africa. For six centuries the Ottoman Empire's vast influence around the Mediterranean basin made it the centre of interaction between the Eastern and Western worlds. After its capture in 1453, Constantinople became the capital city of the Ottoman Empire until its dissolution in the 20th century.
ContentItems.Title: Map of Ottoman Empire 1481-1683

ContentItems.Caption: The controlled use of fire represents an important step in the development of early humans. The first species that is believed to have tamed fire is Homo erectus around 1.5 Ma. Probably used primarily to cook and preserve food, fire distinguished humans from other animals and promoted human development in other areas such as social development and tool making.
ContentItems.Title: Fire

Exhibits.Title: First Evidence of Controlled Use of Fire

ContentItems.Attribution: Uploaded by Wikipedia author Jos-Manuel Benito
ContentItems.Caption: The image shows a typical Acheulean hand-axe taken from a site in the Zamora province of Spain in the Duoro Valley. Acheulean is attributed to an archaeological industry of stone tool manufacture associated with early humans. They are typically found with Homo erectus remains. The primary innovation of the distinctive oval and pear-shaped Acheulean hand-axes is that the stone was worked symmetrically and on both sides (biface tools). The hand-axes were multi-use implements for hacking wood, cutting animal carcasses, scraping hides, digging roots, and/or butchering animals.
ContentItems.Title: Acheulean Handaxe

ContentItems.Caption: Homo neanderthalensis lived in the Northern and Western areas of Eurasia during the Pleistocene epoch of the last ice Age. Neanderthals were short, robust hunter-gatherers that looked very similar to modern humans. They had slightly more pronounced foreheads, wider noses and larger jaws. Like Homo sapiens, Neanderthals created stone tools and weapons. This image shows an artist's rendition of a family of Neanderthals using stone tools.
ContentItems.Title: Artist's rendition of Neanderthal life

ContentItems.Attribution: Uploaded by YouTube user ExpertVillage, Expert: John Olsen, Filmmaker Mike Phillips
ContentItems.Caption: Through scratching and grinding rocks, John Olsen has made many authentic replica artifacts. He majored in ceramics in college and began making primitive items with native clays. Knapping is the shaping of flint, chert, obsidian or other conchoidally-fracturing stone. Knapping is used to manufacture stone tools, strikers, or flat-faced stones for building or facing walls. In cultures that have not adopted metalworking technologies, the production of stone tools by knappers is common.
ContentItems.Title: Flintknapping

ContentItems.Caption: In this video, John Olsen shows how to make a wide variety of stone tools using a hornstone and hammerstone. He creates these tools through the skilled striking of the stones together, as early hominids would have during the Stone Age. In this way, Olsen describes how he can make scrapers, hand axes, arrowheads, and thin blades.
ContentItems.Title: How to make Stone Age tools

ContentItems.Attribution: Photograph uploaded by Wikipedia user Sandstein
ContentItems.Caption: A stone axe in various stages of manufacture, from left to right (finished axe with modern wooden handle). The stone heads are from the Neolithic settlement of Vinelz on Lake Biel, Switzerland, c. 2700 BC. The Neolithic Age of New Stone era is considered the last part of the Stone Age. The Neolithic includes the use of wild and domestic crops and the use of domesticated animals. Neolithic stone implements are by definition polished and, except for specialty items, not chipped.
ContentItems.Title: Neolithic stone axe

ContentItems.Caption: This is a rough sketch of the stone tools found in Olduvai Gorge. Referred to as the Olduwan Tool Industry, these distinctly simplistic implements represent the earliest man-made tools discovered thus far. This drawing shows a chopper, which likely would have been used along with the sharp flakes created from its manufacture to remove the meat from animal bones.
ContentItems.Title: Olduwan chopper stone

ContentItems.Attribution: British Museum reference # 1934, 1214.1   Uploaded by Wikipedia user BabelStone
ContentItems.Caption: The appearance of stone tools in human prehistory is characteristic of the appearance of the genus Homo, including early species such as H. rudolfensis, H. habilis, and H. ergaster. Discovered in the Olduvai Gorge in Tanzania, the earliest stone tools were called Olduwan. They have simple construction - usually a core stone that has been struck and fractured by a hammerstone to create sharp edges.
ContentItems.Title: Olduwan Stone Chopping Tool

ContentItems.Attribution: Uploaded on Flickr by user Stepheye "Stephanie Watson"
ContentItems.Caption: The Stone Age is the first age of the three-age system of archaeology. It is a broad prehistoric period during which stone was widely used in the manufacture of implements with a sharp edge, a point or a percussion surface. Stone was used to make arrow heads, spearpoints and querns. Stone tools may be made of either ground or chipped stone.
ContentItems.Title: Stone Age cutting tool

ContentItems.Caption: Although early tools were traditionally made from striking core stones with hammerstones, shells could also be used in their construction. These prehistoric tools were all made from mussel shells. As can be seen, shells could be formed into many different shapes and implements.
ContentItems.Title: Stone tools made out of mussel shells

ContentItems.Attribution: Uploaded on YouTube by Emory University
ContentItems.Caption: Emory University archaeologist Dietrich Stout delves into the mind of Stone Age toolmakers and describes how the evolution of our ancient ancestors has correlated with the creation of stone tools. Through experimental archaeology, Stout works on understanding how early stone tools were made by attempting the task himself. He describes the skill, knowledge, and precision required for the making of these tools throughout history and what it tells us about the evolving brain and mind of early humans.
ContentItems.Title: The minds of Stone Age toolmakers

ContentItems.Attribution: Craig Benjamin and David Christian lecture slides
ContentItems.Caption: "Lucy" is the name given to an Australopithecus afarensis skeleton discovered in 1974. This is an artist's rendering of how Lucy may have looked in her Ethiopian habitat 3.2 million years ago.
ContentItems.Title: Lucy's World

ContentItems.Attribution: Placed in the public domain by its creator, Wikipedia user Danrha
ContentItems.Caption: "Lucy" (AL 288-1) was the name given to a fossil skeleton of Australopithecus afarensis discovered in 1974 in Ethiopias Afar Desert. Estimated to have lived 3.2 Ma, Lucy provided evidence of small skull capacity and bipedalism in early human evolution, among other notable characteristics. This replica of Lucy is on display in the Museo Nacional de Antropologa in Mexico City.
ContentItems.Title: Replica of "Lucy"

ContentItems.Attribution: Science, 2 October 2009: Vol. 326. no. 5949, pp. 68e1-68e7, Fig. 2
ContentItems.Caption: "Ardi" was the name given to an Ardipithecus ramidus fossil skeleton unearthed in 1994 in Ethiopias Afar Desert. Ardi represented the earliest species of hominine ever found as a relatively complete fossil skeleton. Radiometric dating of volcanic ash encasing the deposits suggests that Ardi lived about 4.4 million years ago, 1 million years before Lucy, a fossil skeleton of Australopithecus afarensis also found in the Afar Desert 20 years earlier.
ContentItems.Title: "Ardi": Reconstruction of fossilized Ardipithecus ramidus skull

ContentItems.Caption: Humans migrated out of Africa and all over the world. 13,000 years ago, humans had already settled on all continents except Antarctica. This process of global colonization, called extensification, refers to the increase in range of humans, but not in density. During the Paleolithic Era, humans were the first large land mammals to spread over much of the globe, showing their ability to adapt to a huge diversity of environments.
ContentItems.Title: Early Human Migration

Exhibits.Title: Evidence of Humans on All Continents Apart from Antarctica

ContentItems.Caption: This is a phylogenetic tree showing the extant hominoids: humans (genus Homo), chimpanzees (genus Pan), gorillas (genus Gorilla), orangutans (genus Pongo), and gibbons (four genera of the family Hylobatidae: Hylobates, Hoolock, Nomascus, and Symphalangus). Only humans, bonobos and chimpanzees belong to the Hominini tribe.
ContentItems.Title: Evolution of Hominoidea

ContentItems.Caption: Salman Khan gives a brief overview of the evolution of humanity. He explains how a meteorite that struck the Earth 65 million years ago exterminated the dinosaurs and opened up new niches for the surviving organisms. One of these surviving organisms was an ancestor that eventually gave rise to modern humans. Through fossil evidence, he creates a general timeline of major events in human evolution.
ContentItems.Title: Human Evolution Overview

ContentItems.Caption: In part 1, David Christian introduces LUCA, or Last Common Universal Ancestor, and introduces how the study of taxonomy can help us visualize our relationships with other organisms. He explains the main types of evidence that scientists use to study human origins and what they may reveal about our ancestors. These types of evidence include our fossil record, genetic dating, and primate studies.
ContentItems.Title: Threshold 6: Origins of Human Beings - Part 1

ContentItems.Caption: In Part 2 youll learn how a mass extinction 65 million years ago was followed by an increase in biodiversity. Mammals flourished, including our tree-dwelling ancestors. Life eventually evolved to include our species, Homo sapiens, but the path was rocky with surprising dead-ends.
ContentItems.Title: Threshold 6: Origins of Human Beings - Part 2

References.Authors: Rebecca L. Cann, Mark Stoneking and Allan C. Wilson
References.Title: Mitochondrial DNA and human evolution

ContentItems.Caption: The first humans to adopt the farming lifestyle probably did so by with their bare hands, sticks or stones. Tools such as knives, scythes, and wooden plows were eventually developed and dominated agriculture for thousands of years. In the early days of agriculture, almost everyone worked in agriculture, because each family could barely grow enough food for themselves with such limited technology. It was not until millennia later when developments in farming methods and technology brought about the possibility of surplus.
ContentItems.Title: Early Agricultural Tools

ContentItems.Attribution: Norman de Garis Davies, Nina Davies
ContentItems.Caption:
This is an agricultural scene from Ancient Egypt. Some estimated dates for the origin and spread of agriculture are as follows:
Eastern USA (4000-3000 BP), Central Mexico (5000-4000 BP), Northern South America (5000-4000 BP), sub-Saharan Africa (5000-4000 BP, exact location unknown), the Fertile Crescent (11000 BP), the Yangtze and Yellow River basins (9000 BP) and the New Guinea Highlands (9000-6000 BP).
ContentItems.Title: Early Depiction of Agriculture

ContentItems.Caption: David Christian discusses whether humans could survive as foragers. He reveals how the world committed to practices of farming in a symbiosis between humans and artificially selected plants. He also explains the effects of farming on the lifestyle of humans, but questions how agriculture appeared in separate core regions throughout the world.
ContentItems.Title: Threshold 7: Origins of Agriculture - Part 1

ContentItems.Caption: See how and why agriculture spread and why David Christian considers it a major threshold of increasing complexity. Christian answers the question of the appearance of separate core regions of agriculture with 2 main reasons: overpopulation and climate change. As a result, certain areas with increasing availability of resources caused foragers to live a more sedentary lifestyle focused on farming.
ContentItems.Title: Threshold 7: Origins of Agriculture - Part 2

References.Publication: The Applied History Research Group and The Learning Commons, University of Calgary
References.Title: Predominant winds and explorers' routes
Easter Island - The Statues and Rock Art of Rapa Nui

ContentItems.Caption: The first birds also evolved during the Jurassic. Archaeopteryx is thought to be the missing link between dinosaurs and modern day birds. The first fossil discovery of archaeopteryx showed clear evidence of feathers and what appeared to be wings. Thought it probably could not fly like modern birds, it probably used it's wings to glide from tree to tree to catch insects and other small prey.
ContentItems.Title: Archeopteryx

ContentItems.Caption: Cryolophosaurus was one of the first large theropod dinosaurs that preyed on other large dinosaurs. It lived during the Early Jurassic and was discovered in Antarctica. One of it's distinctive features was the head crest that was present on most early theropods.
ContentItems.Title: Cryolophosaurus

ContentItems.Caption: Sauropods were the largest land animals ever to exist. Nothing alive today can even compare to how massive they were. Traditionally, they were viewed as slow lumbering beasts that lived near swamps to support their weight. They were also usually depicted with their necks craning and moving like those of swans. However, recent research shows that they were more capable of carrying their own weight and their necks were actually more stiff than expected. This was because their size forced them to be built like suspension bridges, with their long necks supported by their tails as counterweights.
ContentItems.Title: Sauropods

ContentItems.Caption: The Jurassic period saw dinosaurs creep out from their small beginnings and flourish. The climate was favorable and the continents were breaking apart, creating fertile shallow seas and many miles of coast line which improved rain patterns. These conditions allowed dinosaurs to grow to enormous sizes, as both predator and prey attempted to gain the upper hand on one another. Sauropods were the extreme example, growing to sizes sometimes of over 100 feet in length, they used their size as a deterrent against predators and to control a niche in their environment that no other creature could access. They were eating machines designed to process huge amounts of foliage. And they did so so quickly that they had not time to chew. In fact, they ate small stones so that the plant matter would get ground up within their stomach's. Apatosaurus is probably the most well known of all sauropods, but is likely known by it's older name by many which is Brontosaurus.
ContentItems.Title: Size Matters

ContentItems.Caption: The Triassic-Jurassic Mass extinction in many ways finished what the previous mass extinction started. It coincides with the break up of Pangaea and thus with a period of once again, increased volcanism. The world still hadnt fully recovered from the previous mass extinction when this one began but it would after this one. The Triassic period marked a time of competition between groups of animals for dominance over the land. There were many groups contending for the position, and among them were the dinosaurs. During this time dinosaurs still hadnt claimed their rule over the land as the dominant vertebrates, but when this extinction eradicated many other kinds of large reptiles, dinosaurs moved into their niches and were the only type of large terrestrial vertebrate for the next almost 150 million years.
ContentItems.Title: Triassic-Jurassic Mass Extinction

ContentItems.Caption: We know that all the continents were together in one land mass because fossil evidence shows animals and plants of the same species were present across different continents that are now separated by thousands of miles of ocean, but must have then been together geographically.
ContentItems.Title: Fossil Evidence

ContentItems.Caption: This was the first period where evidence of dinosaurs is present, though they were not there at the very beginning. It began right after the Permian mass extinction which wiped out 90% of all life and marks the beginning of the Mesozoic Era. Although dinosaurs are present, they are not the dominant form of reptile at first and had to compete with close relatives such as the Rausuchians, which were crocodile-like creatures, and other mammal-like reptiles such as Placerias. In the end though, they were triumphant, and almost all the competition died out by the Jurassic. This is an image of Herrerasaurus, one of the first dinosaurs.
ContentItems.Title: Herrerasaurus

ContentItems.Caption: The triassic world was not very pleasant. The continents were all joined together in one giant landmass call Pangaea. This reduced coastlines and created a large inland are that would heat up and not have the same tempering from the sea as coastal areas. As a result, large deserts formed and they stretched from pole to pole. It was only in the polar regions that there were monsoons that allowed more plant growth. And it wasn't until the continents started to break apart that dinosaurs truly began to flourish.
ContentItems.Title: Hostile World

ContentItems.Caption: One of the other kinds of large land reptiles present during the Triassic was Placerias. It was a large ground herbivore which used it's tusks to dig up roots and as defense. It, and its kind went extinct at the end of the Triassic period, leaving room for the dinosaurs to take over.
ContentItems.Title: Placerias

ContentItems.Caption: One of the first herbivorous dinosaurs, Plateosaurus was a large prosauropod, a group that would later give rise to some of the largest creatures of all time such as apatosaurus and diplodocus.
ContentItems.Title: Plateosaurus

ContentItems.Caption: This crocodile-like reptile was related to dinosaurs and fell into a group called archosaurs which encompasses everything from crocodiles to birds. They ultimately went extinct at the end of the Triassic.
ContentItems.Title: Proterosuchus

ContentItems.Caption: These flying reptiles can also trace their origins back to the Triassic. Though small at first, they grew to enormous sizes in the Cretaceous. They were the second animal group to achieve true flight, after insects.
ContentItems.Title: Pterosaurs

ContentItems.Caption: These were reptiles that were similar to carnivorous dinosaurs in many ways except they were too top heavy to walk on their hind legs. They were the top predators in most Triassic ecosystems, and though the smaller dinosaurs were more swift than them, they could steal their kills because of their size. The ultimately could not compete with them in the changing environment and disappeared by the end of the Triassic
ContentItems.Title: Rauisuchians

ContentItems.Caption: During the Triassic the first marine reptiles began to emerge. The first to truly adapt to a marine lifestyle were the ichthyosaurs. They actually attained a fish-like appearance and were similar to today's dolphin's or shark's. They even developed a way to not have to leave the ocean to give birth, unlike other marine reptiles such as turtles and plesiosaurs.
ContentItems.Title: Sea Life

ContentItems.Caption: This mass extinction wiped out 96% of all marine species and 70% of terrestrial vertebrate species, making it the biggest of all time.  It marked the end of the Paleozoic Eon and the beginning of the Mesozoic Eon and the age of the dinosaurs. The creation of the super continent Pangaea was the main cause of the extinction. When all the continents came together, thousands of miles of coastline disappeared, creating a huge inland desert that stretched from pole to pole. In addition the Siberian Traps, a huge area with large amounts of volcanic activity formed during this time, releasing massive amounts of CO2 into the air. This increase in greenhouse gases combined with the newly formed supercontinent disrupted ocean currents, causing them to stagnate, releasing millions of tons of methane and CO2 into the atmosphere, creating a feedback looped that raised temperatures by almost 12 degrees Fahrenheit, devastating all life on earth.
ContentItems.Title: Permian-Triassic Mass Extinction

ContentItems.Caption: Angiosperms, more commonly known as flowering plants, first appeared in the Cretaceous period. They provided an efficient alliance between insects and plants in that pollination was now carried out via animals and not just the wind and water. This way, plants did not have to create as much pollen and could rely on specific species of insects to carry their pollen to other plants of the same species. Thus a beautiful symbiosis emerged, and allowed an explosion of biodiversity.
ContentItems.Title: Angiosperms

ContentItems.Caption: Another carnivore that was probably bigger than T-Rex that lived in South America during the early Cretaceous was Giganotosaurus. It looked similar to T-Rex, except for having 3 claws rather than 2. It was the apex predator of the region and probably preyed on huge prey such as Argentinasaurus, the heaviest sauropod of all time.
ContentItems.Title: Giganotosaurus

ContentItems.Caption: Spinosaurus was probably the largest land carnivore of all time, larger even than T-Rex. It had a distinctive sail on it's back and had a snout shaped more like that of a crocodile's than other dinosaur's. It lived in the Cretaceous in North Africa
ContentItems.Title: Spinosaurus

ContentItems.Caption: The Cretaceous saw the greatest diversification of dinosaurs and their complete specialization in occupying every possible niche in the environment. The emergence of birds and flowering plants are defining features of this period and mammals began to diversify to some degree as well. Ultimately all non-avian dinosaurs went extinct at the end of the Cretaceous because of an asteroid impact. Tyrannosaurus was at the tail end of the Cretaceous period and was the top predator of the time.
ContentItems.Title: Tyrannosaurus

ContentItems.Caption: This Mass Extinction does not seem to have as clear causes as many of the other, though we know that around 50% of generas were wiped out by it. The cause is difficult to pin on a single event but we do know that these were times of environmental change and these changes are what caused the extinction. One suggested theory is that the evolution of plants caused an increase in erosion because they became taller and acquired deeper roots. This would have in turn fertilized the oceans very suddenly, causing large algal blooms that resulted in large anoxic events, suffocating marine life. In addition, the additional plant matter would have sequestered a large amount of carbon from the atmosphere, causing a glaciation. With fewer burrowing organisms and no large plant eaters at the time, these plants created large coal deposits, and in the process, they would have cooled the earth.
ContentItems.Title: Late Devonian Mass Extinction

ContentItems.Caption: The first of 5 large mass extinction events, the Ordovician-Silurian extinction event marked a time where nearly 60% of marine invertebrates died off. In terms of the % of genera wiped out, it is the second largest, only behind the Permian-Triassic Mass Extinction.The generally accepted theory is that a large amount of CO2 was sequestered during that time and this caused a drop in global temperatures creating an ice age. We know of this because of glacial deposits in the Sahara desert. The end of the ice age saw a rise in sea levels and an increase in biodiversity among the survivors of this event
ContentItems.Title: Ordovician-Silurian extinction event

ContentItems.Caption: Asteroids are solid extraterrestrial bodies that can be made from a variety of elements or metals. They can be large but they are not large enough to have a round shape like planets. The one wiped out the dinosaurs was most probably around the size of Mt. Everest, moving at a speed of several kilometers per second. When it hit, it released the equivalent amount of energy of around 2 million times that of the largest thermonuclear weapon ever tested.
ContentItems.Title: Asteroids

ContentItems.Caption: After the impact, the world took many years to recover. And when it did, things did not return to the way they were. Everything that was larger than 50 pounds was wiped out and that left a lot of niches that needed to be filled. Now that the dinosaurs were gone, the mammals were able to adapt and grow into a variety of forms very quickly that would allow them to take their place.
ContentItems.Title: Cenozoic Life

ContentItems.Caption: The Cretaceous-Tertiary Mass Extinction is probably the best known and understood of Big Five mass extinctions. It is the most recent and infamous for the disappearance of all non-avian dinosaurs. For years the reason behind the extinction event went unknown, until Professor Walter Alvarez discovered a layer of Iridium that suggested an asteroid impact. After many years of research and the discovery of a large crater on the Yucatan peninsula in Mexico, it is now well established that the demise of the dinosaurs came from outer space. The impact created a tsunami that ravaged the Atlantic coast and the heat from it caused forest fires all over the north America. The rock that was ejected from the impact flew into space rained fire back down onto the earth, making the devastation global. The event caused essentially every creature larger than 50 pounds to die out, wiping out all dinosaur species, except for birds and leaving mammals and empty world to populate.
ContentItems.Title: Cretaceous-Tertiary Mass Extinction

ContentItems.Caption: The CretaceousPaleogene extinction event occurred approximately 65.5 million years ago (Ma) at the end of the Maastrichtian age of the Cretaceous period. It was a large-scale mass extinction of animal and plant species in a geologically short period of time. In 1980, a team of researchers consisting of Nobel prizewinning physicist Luis Alvarez, his son geologist Walter Alvarez, and chemists Frank Asaro and Helen Michel discovered that sedimentary layers found all over the world at the CretaceousTertiary boundary contain a concentration of iridium many times greater than normal (30, 160 and 20 times in three sections originally studied).
ContentItems.Threshold: 4. Origins of the Earth and Solar System
ContentItems.Title: Dinosaur Extinction Impact: 65.5 Ma

ContentItems.Caption: The only thing that remains of dinosaurs today are their fossils; bones, teeth, shells, feces or even skin that have been mineralized and preserved over millions of years. Fossils are the only way we know of the existence of dinosaurs, and because we do not find them after the K-T boundary, we assume that the impact event is what caused their extinction.
ContentItems.Title: Dinosaur Fossils

ContentItems.Caption: The impact would have created a crater much like this one, only many times larger. For many years it could not be found and it was thought that it had been subducted under the earth's crust or covered by antarctic ice sheets. But when tsunami deposits were found on the gulf of mexico that matched the time of impact, the search narrowed.
ContentItems.Title: Impact Crater

ContentItems.Caption: The force of the impact would have created a tidal wave that washed up all around the atlantic ocean, specifically the gulf of mexico. This tsunami would have been so large that it would have ripped up seabed while it moved across the continental shelf along with the coastal forests lining the gulf. This is how deep sea deposits were seen littered with wood fragments that could have gotten mixed no other way.
ContentItems.Title: Impact Tsunami

ContentItems.Caption: Iridium is an element that is quite rare on Earth's surface but is common in asteroids and outer space. A layer of iridium was found around the world that was deposited at the same time. The presence of such high amounts of iridium indicated that there must have been some kind of impact around that time. This was further supported by other kinds of evidence like glass spherules, shocked quartz, and tsunami deposits.
ContentItems.Title: Iridium

ContentItems.Caption: Asteroid impacts are so devastating because they release a lot of energy very quickly. This is because the equation for kinetic energy depends on the mass of the object and the square of its speed. Because the Earth's gravity does a lot to speed up the asteroid, it can reach speeds of several kilometers per second. If the object is small, friction from the atmosphere will tend to vaporize it before it reaches the ground creating meteors, also known as falling stars. But if the object is large, there isn't much that can slow it down and when it collides with earth it unleashes a lot of devastation. The one that wiped out the dinosaurs is thought to have been between 6 and 9 miles long.
ContentItems.Title: Physics of Impacts

ContentItems.Caption: When tsunami deposits were found along the gulf of mexico, the search for the impact site eventually led to the Yucatan peninsula in Mexico. The crater was huge, spanning several hundred kilometers in diameter. The force of the impact would have caused limestone on the continental shelf to vaporize, releasing massive amounts of CO2. The blast would have caused fires all along the americas and the ejecta that was shot into space from the impact would rain back down all over the world as molten spheres of rock. The dust cloud blocked the sun for years and when it cleared, the dinosaurs would be gone.
ContentItems.Title: Yucatan

ContentItems.Caption: Birds are the direct descendants of dinosaurs. They evolved during the jurassic period from small theropod dinosaurs and diversified into a hugely successful group of animals. They are characterized by being endothermic, oviparous and having feathers. It is thought that dinosaurs must have undergone a process of neoteny when evolving into birds. This means that the adult members of the species retained many traits specific to juveniles of that species. The main trait that is thought to have been passed on like this is feathers. The young dinosaurs would develop the downy feathers that characterize young birds today in order to keep warm, and over time these feathers would have evolved other uses such as for display, gliding and eventually flying.
ContentItems.Title: Birds

ContentItems.Caption:
After the Permian Mass-Extinction, the largest single mass extinction of all time, two important groups of vertebrates rose from the ashes and would come to shape and dominate the next two eras of planet earth. The first were the archosaurs, a group that used to be represented by the dinosaurs, but who today only consist of birds and crocodiles. For 185 million years they ruled the earth marking the Mesozoic as the Age of the Dinosaurs.
The second important group of animals to arise came from small group of synapsids or mammal-like reptiles. Here we find our own origins. The first were small during the time of the dinosaurs, but once the asteroid hit, everything heavier than 50 pounds was wiped out leaving a huge vacuum of niches in the environment for mammals to grow into, allowing them to claim the Cenozoic as the Age of Mammals. Within a few million years, mammals had diversified into a myriad of forms, one of which was the common ancestor of all primates and human beings.
ContentItems.Title: Higher Vertebrates

ContentItems.Caption: Mammals first appeared sometime during the Mesozoic during the time of the dinosaurs. Though their ancestors, the mammal-like reptiles known as therapsids, were dominant before the appearance of dinosaurs, they declined after the Permian mass extinction, and all but disappeared after the Triassic mass extinction. Every mammal has fur (though whales only have a few vestigial hairs), produces milk for their young and is warm blooded. Though they evolved from small rodent-like ancestors, mammals now occupy almost every niche imaginable and have a huge number of body plans for their different lifestyles. Their high metabolic rates have allowed them to evolve into far more behaviorally sophisticated creatures than most reptiles and is what has allowed so many
ContentItems.Title: Mammals

ContentItems.Caption: Anapsids are a class of reptile that consists of modern day turtles, tortoises and their extinct relatives. They are characterized by a lack of openings behind their skull, though they are thought to have had a common ancestor with other modern reptiles, dinosaurs and birds.They originated in the Carboniferous.
ContentItems.Title: Sauropsids: Anapsids

ContentItems.Caption: Diapsids are and were a very prevalent group of higher vertebrates. They get their name from the two openings they have in the back of their skull, behind their eyes. Currently the group consists of lizards, snakes, crocodiles and birds but once was characterized by dinosaurs, plesiosaurs, ichthyosaurs and pterosaurs, occupying every niche in the environment. Much of this group was wiped out during the K-T mass extinction event, decimating many of the larger members of this clade such as all non-avian dinosaurs.
ContentItems.Title: Sauropsids: Diapsids

ContentItems.Caption: Modern mammals are part of a group of vertebrates known as synapsids. They are distinguished by a single hole in their skull behind their eyes. Synapsids originated around 320 million years ago and and were a very diverse group, dominating much of the world's ecosystems until the permian mass extinction. After that, one main group known as the therapsids, of which mammals are a part of, survived and only began to flourish again after the dinosaur's went extinct 65 million years ago.
ContentItems.Title: Synapsids

ContentItems.Caption: Salman Khan clarifies the first life found on land. The first life to venture on to land was algae at 1.2 billion years ago. Animals ventured onto land before plants existed on land, but did so only for a short period of their lives to possibly lay eggs. Their offspring would then spend the majority of their life in the ocean. Plants were the first organisms live their whole life on land because they developed a vascular system where they could retain water. Animals needed more time to develop and also needed plants to create an ecosystem that was hospitable.
ContentItems.Title: First Animals on Land

ContentItems.Caption: The colonization of land provided life with a new set of challenges, though none insurmountable. By departing the seas, life had to face desiccation, additional radiation from the sun and gravity. Many adaptations that were suitable for a marine environment were not of much use on land. Plants were among the first pioneers to leave the seas. They developed an intricate vascular system for support and transport and eventually set the stage for animals to leave the ocean to carve out a living on land.
ContentItems.Title: Vascular Plants

ContentItems.Caption:
Conventional classification has living vertebrates grouped into seven classes based on traditional interpretations of gross anatomical and physiological traits. This classification is the one most commonly encountered in school textbooks, overviews, non-specialist, and popular works. The extant vertebrates are:
    Subphylum Vertebrata
        Class Agnatha (jawless fishes)
        Class Chondrichthyes (cartilaginous fishes)
        Class Osteichthyes (bony fishes)
        Class Amphibia (amphibians)
        Class Reptilia (reptiles)
        Class Aves (birds)
        Class Mammalia (mammals). 
In addition to these comes two classes of extinct armoured fishes, the Placodermi and the Acanthodii.
ContentItems.Title: Vertebrata

ContentItems.Caption: The first vertebrates appeared around 450 million years ago. They were small creatures, similar to today's hagfish. They had no jaws, they were small, and they were at the bottom of the food chain. They did however carry the blueprint for all vertebrates alive today and possessed some of the basic features present in modern vertebrates such as a dorsal nerve chord, a post-anal tail, pharyngial gill slits and basic brains. Over time, they slowly grew in size and diversified into all the forms that we see today.
ContentItems.Title: Vertebrates

ContentItems.Attribution: Craig Benjamin and David Christian lecture slides
ContentItems.Caption: Craig Benjamin and David Christian outline the 8 major steps in the evolution of life on Earth.
ContentItems.Title: 8 Important Steps

ContentItems.Caption: Fossilized stromatolites, an early Pre-Cambrian form of life.  Stromatolites are considered to be some of the first evidence of life on Earth.
ContentItems.Title: Stromatolites

ContentItems.Caption: In Part 1, David Christian explains the Goldilocks Conditions that helped life form and prosper.
ContentItems.Title: Threshold 5: Origins of Life - Part 1

ContentItems.Caption: Part 2 explains the relationship between the different qualities of life, takes a closer look at DNA and introduces Charles Darwins work on the theory of evolution.
ContentItems.Title: Threshold 5: Origins of Life - Part 2
